page.title: Canadian Criminal Sentencing/Procedure/Notice of Increased Penalty

revision.text:
==General Principles== Certain offences mandate higher penalties where there is a prior conviction for the offence. The higher penalty can only be sought where the Crown has given notice of their intention to seek greater punishment. Offences for which this applies include: * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Use of Firearm in Commission of an Offence|use firearm]] (s. 85) * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Unsafe Storage of a Firearm|careless storage of a firearm]] (86) * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Possession of Unauthorized Firearm|possession firearm]] (92) * betting, pool-selling, bookmaking (202) * placing bets on other’s behalf (203) * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Impaired Driving and Over 80|impaired driving and over 80]] (253) * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Refusal|refusal]] (254) By failing to give proper notice the Crown cannot rely upon the legislated mandatory minimums. However, a judge may still consider the prior record when sentencing and can impose the mandatory minimum as long as it is in the range of sentence. R v Norris, (1988) 41 C.C.C. (3d) 441 (N.W.T.C.A.) {{reflist|2}} ==Notice== Notice of increased penalty is governed by s. 727(1): {{quotation| 727. (1) Subject to subsections (3) and (4), where an accused or a defendant is convicted of an offence for which a greater punishment may be imposed by reason of previous convictions, no greater punishment shall be imposed on him by reason thereof unless the prosecutor satisfies the court that the accused or defendant, before making his plea, was notified that a greater punishment would be sought by reason thereof. |[http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/rsc-1985-c-c-46/latest/rsc-1985-c-c-46.html#sec727 CCC]}} Section 727(1) does not specifically require written notice, thus, both written or verbal notice is sufficient.R v Collini (1979) 3 MVR 218 (Ont HCJ) There is divided cases on whether the accused must be served personally or whether service on the agent or counsel is sufficient. R. v. Beaulieu; R. v. Lepine (1979), 50 C.C.C. (2d) 189 (Que. S.C.)
 The dominant opinion however has been that service of notice upon counsel is sufficient to satisfy the requirements of s.727(1) and that personal service is not necessary. R. v. Fowler, (1982), 2 C.C.C. (3d) 227 (NSCA)
R. v. Simms, (1986), 31 C.C.C. (3d) 350 (NLCA)
R. v. Godon, (1984), 12 C.C.C. (3d) 446, (SKCA)
R. v. Van Boeyen, 1996 CanLII 8372 (BC CA)
 In select jurisdictions, such as Saskatchewan, it has been determined that service upon an agent, including a relative, is also sufficient.R. v. Godon, (1984), 12 C.C.C. (3d) 446, (SKCA) It is not sufficient to notify the accused that the Crown “may” be seeking a greater punishment. R . v. Riley (1982), 69 C.C.C. (2d) 245 (Ont. High Ct.) It is not necessary to notify the accused of the nature and character of the penalty sought, including the length of the possible jail sentence. R v Bear (1979), 47 C.C.C. (2d) 462 (Sask C.A.) There is no need for “reasonable notice”. So notice can be given on the day of trial.R v Bufford (1988) 46 CCC (3d) 116 (Ont.DC) Notice must be given to the accused of the Crown's intention to seek a greater penalty for past offences.R. v. Zaccaria, 2005 ABCA 130 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ab/abca/doc/2005/2005abca130/2005abca130.html]; R. v. Veinot (1983), NSCA__ Although it is generally practiced, it is not necessary to specify the previous convictions being relied upon when giving notice.R v Pidlubny (1973) 10 CCC (2d) 178 (ONCA) There are two lines of cases on the issue of whether the notice is discretionary on the judge to accept. This turns on whether the notice is part of the core prosecutorial duties which are not reviewable by a court absent evidence of abuse of process or bad faith. R. v. Haneveld 2008 ABPC 382 - not reviewable by court
R. v. Gill, [http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onsc/doc/2011/2011onsc1145/2011onsc1145.html 2011 ONSC 1145] - reviewable by court
 Cases is support of the crown discretion view suggests that to do otherwise would create too much second guessing and erode the boundary between the separatoin of powers. R v Mohla [2012] OJ No. 388 at 164 Where the crown does not serve proper notice under s. 727, then the accused cannot be said to have been convicted "of an offence that is punishable by a minimum term of imprisonment" under s.742.1, and so would not disqualify the offender from being subject to a conditional sentence. R. v. Demchuk, [http://canlii.ca/t/l0l 2003 CanLII 15723] (ON CA) {{reflist|2}} {{BookCat}}

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Canadian Criminal Sentencing/Procedure/Notice of Increased Penalty]]

==Evidence== The admissibility of evidence is significantly different in a sentencing hearings than in trials. The interests at stake differ in a sentencing as opposed to a trial as the presumption of innocence is gone and there is no longer a concern for a wrongful conviction. R. v. Angelillo, [http://canlii.ca/t/1q3xt 2006 SCC 55] (CanLII), [2006] 2 SCR 728 such as at para. 30 In sentencing, courts should be open to a broad range of information in order to achieve the objectives under the Code. R. v. Jones, [http://canlii.ca/t/1frtc 1994 CanLII 85] (SCC), [1994] 2 SCR 229 at p.396 ("...both the public interest in safety and the general sentencing interest of developing the most appropriate penalty for the particular offender dictate the greatest possible range of information on which to make an accurate evaluation of the ganger posed by the offender.") and at p. 398 ("sentencing judge is to obtain the accurate assessment of the offender that is necessary to develop an appropriate sentence, he will have to have at his disposal the broadest possible range of information."(
However, the evidence must still meet the standard of accuracy, credibility and reliability. McWilliams' Canadian Criminal Evidence, Fourth Edition at 34:10
R. v. Lévesque, [http://canlii.ca/t/523w 2000 SCC 47] (CanLII), [2000] 2 SCR 487 at para. 30
R. v. Campbell, [http://canlii.ca/t/f6k 2003 CanLII 49352] (ON SC) at para. 31
Angelillo at para. 20 The prejudicial effect of the evidence should not outweigh the probative value. Angelillo at para. 32
R. v. Edwards, [http://canlii.ca/t/1fbx6 2001 CanLII 24105] (ON CA) at para. 63 Campbell
 Exclusionary rules of evidence are not applied strictly in sentencing. Campbell at para. 29, 31, 32
R. v. Boyd, [http://canlii.ca/t/23m12 1983 CanLII 240] (BC CA)
 Admissibility voir dires, such as for voluntariness, may be held but are not necessary. Campbell at para. 9 In 1996, Part XXIII was amended to create a statutory framework for sentencing hearings. Angelillo, such as at para. 21 The law of evidence at sentencing equally applies to dangerous and long term offenders. R. v. Johnson, [http://canlii.ca/t/51pl 2003 SCC 46] (CanLII), [2003] 2 SCR 357 at para. 23 '''Character Evidence'''
Character evidence is admissible and relevant to sentencing. Edwards at para.39-42
Angelillo at para. 28, 29 Character evidence may be excluded where fairness would outweigh the probative value.Angelillo at para. 32
Ewards at para. 63 {{reflist|2}} ===Factual findings=== Section 723 codifies the common law rules on submission of evidence on sentencing. {{quotation| '''Submissions on facts'''
723. (1) Before determining the sentence, a court shall give the prosecutor and the offender an opportunity to make submissions with respect to any facts relevant to the sentence to be imposed.

'''Submission of evidence'''
(2) The court shall hear any relevant evidence presented by the prosecutor or the offender.

'''Production of evidence'''
(3) The court may, on its own motion, after hearing argument from the prosecutor and the offender, require the production of evidence that would assist it in determining the appropriate sentence.

'''Compel appearance'''
(4) Where it is necessary in the interests of justice, the court may, after consulting the parties, compel the appearance of any person who is a compellable witness to assist the court in determining the appropriate sentence.

...

R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 723; 1995, c. 22, s. 6.

...

'''Information accepted'''
724. (1) In determining a sentence, a court may accept as proved any information disclosed at the trial or at the sentencing proceedings and any facts agreed on by the prosecutor and the offender. |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec723 CCC] }} On a guilty plea, a judge may rely on facts that are agreed upon by the parties. The Crown will read the facts alleged as well as submit allegations of prior criminal convictions. e.g. R v Bartlett, [http://canlii.ca/t/1m697 2005 NLCA 75] (CanLII) The Defence must have an opportunity to deny or consent to the allegations. R. v. Cataract (1994), 93 CCC 486 (SaskCA) In practice, at a minimum the crown should read-in enough facts to make out the essential elements of the offence. Preferably there should also be all admitted facts going to aggravating and mitigating factors. The judge may rely upon any information placed before him. This includes submissions by Crown and Defence counsel as well as admissible evidence. R v Bartlett [http://canlii.ca/t/1m697 2005 NLCA 75] (CanLII) A guilty plea is only an admission of the essential elements of the offence.R. v. Gardiner, [1982] 368 S.C.R. 2 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/1982/1982canlii30/1982canlii30.html 1982 CanLII 30] at 330 and 331 On sentencing, where facts are not in dispute, the judge may makes inferences from proven or undisputed evidence.R. v. Ducharme, [http://canlii.ca/t/fr0w3 2012 MBCA 35] at para 5 {{reflist|2}} ===Disputed of facts=== {{quotation| 724.

...

'''Disputed facts'''
(3) Where there is a dispute with respect to any fact that is relevant to the determination of a sentence, :(a) the court shall request that evidence be adduced as to the existence of the fact unless the court is satisfied that sufficient evidence was adduced at the trial; :(b) the party wishing to rely on a relevant fact, including a fact contained in a presentence report, has the burden of proving it; :(c) either party may cross-examine any witness called by the other party; :(d) subject to paragraph (e), the court must be satisfied on a balance of probabilities of the existence of the disputed fact before relying on it in determining the sentence; and :(e) the prosecutor must establish, by proof beyond a reasonable doubt, the existence of any aggravating fact or any previous conviction by the offender.

|R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 724; 1995, c. 22, s. 6.|[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec724 CCC] }} Where there is a dispute on facts, the court cannot rely upon the crown's version without supported facts. R. v. Choice Atlantic Seafoods Inc., 2001 NSSC 161 at para. 7 To settle the conflict the judge must hear evidence to settle the evidence or chose to accept the accused's version "so far as possible". s. 724(3)(e)
R. v. Choice Atlantic Seafoods Inc., 2001 NSSC 161 at para. 7 citing R. v. Poorman 1991 CanLII 2759 (SK C.A.), (1991), 6 C.R. (4th) 364 (Sask. C.A.) If the difference amounts to a dispute between characterizations, the Defence must call evidence. R. v. Poulin, [http://www.canlii.org/en/bc/bcca/doc/1995/1995canlii2368/1995canlii2368.html 1995 CanLII 2368] (BCCA) Aggravating facts must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt by the crown. R. v. Larche, [http://canlii.ca/t/1q3xv#par43 2006 SCC 56], [2006] 2 S.C.R. 762 at para. 43-44 R. v. Tomdio-Yiuiti, [http://www.canlii.org/en/sk/skca/doc/2010/2010skca81/2010skca81.html 2010 SKCA 81]
R. v. Malinowski, [http://canlii.ca/t/1r2qg 2007 SKCA 33] at para. 6
R. v. Lewis, 2012 NLCA 11, ("an aggravating factor that is disputed is, like an essential element of the offence, required to be proven beyond a reasonable doubt.") R. v. Gardiner, [http://canlii.ca/t/1lpcq 1982 CanLII 30] (S.C.C.), [1982] 2 S.C.R. 368 at p. 414-5
R. v. Angelillo [http://canlii.ca/t/1q3xt 2006 SCC 55] (CanLII), (2006), 214 C.C.C. (3d) 309 (S.C.C.), ("the extrinsic evidence is contested, the prosecution must prove it. Since the facts in question will doubtless be aggravating facts, they must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt (s. 724(3)(e)). The court can sentence the offender only for the offence of which he or she has been convicted, and the sentence must be proportionate to the gravity of that offence...")
 A "Gardiner Hearing" refers to the hearing of oral evidence that is conducted at sentencing where there is a dispute between the parties as to the facts on a guilty plea. see R. v. Gardiner, 1982 CanLII 30 (SCC), [1982] 2 S.C.R. 368 (the "issue should be resolved by ordinary legal principles governing criminal proceedings") This hearing is conducted according to s. 724(3). It will concern the “extrinsic evidence” that must be proven by the crown.R. v. Angelillo 2006 SCC 55 (CanLII), (2006), 214 C.C.C. (3d) 309 (S.C.C.), The Crown does not have to prove voluntariness of statements made by the accused. R v Lees, [1979] 2 SCR 749 {{Reflist|2}} ===Hearsay=== Hearsay is admissible in sentencing under s. 723. {{quotation| s. 723.

...

'''Hearsay evidence'''
(5) Hearsay evidence is admissible at sentencing proceedings, but the court may, if the court considers it to be in the interests of justice, compel a person to testify where the person :(a) has personal knowledge of the matter; :(b) is reasonably available; and :(c) is a compellable witness.

R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 723; 1995, c. 22, s. 6. |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec723 CCC] }} As with all evidence at sentencing, it must be credible and reliable. R v Francis (2005) CCC (3d) 147 at para. 24, 27
R v JPL 2006 ABPC 313 at para. 5
R. v. Janes Family Foods Ltd., [http://canlii.ca/t/1vfxq 2008 ONCJ 13] (CanLII) Documentary evidence, such as reports, records, and assessments, may be admitted for the truth of its contents. R. v. McKay, [http://canlii.ca/t/1hf8d 2004 MBQB 146] at para. 4-9
R. v. Ellard, [http://canlii.ca/t/1n161 2005 BCSC 1087] (CanLII) at para. 22
 The flexible standard may not apply where the Crown wishes to prove aggravating factors which requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt. R. v. Piche, [http://canlii.ca/t/1nxq3 2006 ABCA 220] (CanLII) at para. 14-16
Levesque at para. 30
Angelillo at para. 20, 21
 {{Reflist|2}} ===Evidence of Untried Offences=== Evidence of untried offences is generally a form of character evidence and may be admissible. R. v. McCauley, [2007] O.J. No. 1593 (S.C.)
R. v. Fouquet, [http://canlii.ca/t/1lkj3 2005 ABQB 673] (CanLII)
 Factors to consider whether untried conduct is admissible to establish character includes the following: R. v. Edwards, [http://canlii.ca/t/1fbx6 2001 CanLII 24105] (ON CA) # the nexus between the evidence and the offence for which the offender was convicted—the closer the connection the more likely the evidence will shed light on the circumstances of the charged offence; # the similarity between the evidence and the offence for which the offender was convicted; # the difficulty the offender may encounter in properly defending against the allegations in the proposed evidence; # the danger that the sentence hearing will be unduly prolonged; # the danger that the focus of the sentence hearing will appear to be diverted from the true purpose of imposing a fit sentence for the charged offence that is proportionate to the gravity of the offence and the degree of responsibility of the offender in accordance with s. 718.1; # whether, as in Lees, the offender has adduced evidence of good character; and # the cogency of the proposed evidence. {{reflist|2}} ===Post-Sentence evidence=== See: [[Canadian_Criminal_Procedure_and_Practice/Appeals]] {{BookCat}}

==Introduction== A plea bargain is an agreement between the Crown and defence whereby the Defence agrees to plead guilty to particular offences in exchange for a particular proposal on sentence. If the defence accepts the offer on sentence, the agreement is put the judge as a jointly recommended sentence. ==Joint Recommendations== A joint recommendation is an agreement on penalty between the Crown and Defence to present a single penalty recommendation that the judge is asked to adopt. A joint recommendation does not need to encompass all aspects of the sentence. There can be a joint recommendation on part of a sentence, such as the form of penalty, while still keeping aspects of the penalty in dispute, such as the length of the penalty, conditions associated with the penalty, or ancillary orders.e.g. R. v. Parsons, [http://canlii.ca/t/fvf3f 2012 CanLII 81320] (NL SCTD) - length of CSO and ancillary orders in dispute alone A joint submission often indicates a lower range of sentence. R v Kane [http://canlii.ca/t/fs972 2012 NLCA 53] The motivation for an agreement is often due to a weak aspect in the Crown's case or the risk of the judge giving a higher penalty than what would sought by defence without an agreement. A joint recommendation may even be accepted where it is more lenient than the lower end of the normal range.R v Oake [http://canlii.ca/t/28pd1 2010 NLCA 19] at 64 Sentences arising from a joint recommendation "have little or no precedential value." R. v. Johnston, [http://canlii.ca/t/fmqxj 2011 NLCA 56]
R. v. Johnson, [http://canlii.ca/t/2ct1p 2010 ABQB 546]
R. v. Benlolo [http://canlii.ca/t/1nj8l 2006 CanLII 19284] (ON CA), (2006), 81 O.R. (3d) 440 (C.A.)
 '''Deference'''
A joint recommended sentence is a sentence for which the courts do not readily overturn. R. v. J.W.I.B., [http://canlii.ca/t/58s1 2003 MBCA 92]
R. v. Pashe (S.J.) [http://canlii.ca/t/1pfkc 1995 CanLII 6256] (MB C.A.) The court may only do so where the sentence in not within a reasonably appropriate range for the circumstances. R. v. Smith, [http://canlii.ca/t/1jj1t 2004 BCCA 657]
R. v. Gartner, [http://canlii.ca/t/2fptk 2010 BCCA 600]
R. v. Wickstrom, [http://canlii.ca/t/flrqw 2011 BCSC 745]
R. v. Cerasuolo [http://canlii.ca/t/1fbn2 2001 CanLII 24172] (ON CA)
R. v. DeSousa, [http://canlii.ca/t/fr17k 2012 ONCA 254]
 The judge must give reasons for not adopting a joint recommendation. A judge should give serious consideration to a joint sentencing proposal.R v GWC, [http://canlii.ca/t/5rmx 2000 ABCA 333] at para 17 There is less weight given to "joint recommendations" that do not involve a "quid pro quo" (i.e. some reduced recommendation on sentence).R. v. Wolonciej, [http://www.canlii.org/en/mb/mbca/doc/2011/2011mbca91/2011mbca91.html 2011 MBCA 91] at 10 Likewise, where the accused was without counsel less deference is given.R. v. Bambrick, [http://www.canlii.org/en/nl/nlca/doc/2011/2011nlca79/2011nlca79.html 2011 NLCA 79] at para. 14 '''When Not Followed'''
If a judge has reservations to adopt a joint recommendations it should allow counsel an opportunity to respond. R v GWC, 2000 ABCA 333 (CanLII), 2000 ABCA 333 at 26 Likewise, where a judge is looking to go beyond the range set by counsel, the judge should equally provide notice to the parties before going above or below the range. R v Hood, [http://canlii.ca/t/flqvp 2011 ABCA 169] at 14
R v Abel, [http://canlii.ca/t/fm1mv 2011 NWTCA 4] at 23
R. v. Burback, [http://canlii.ca/t/fq14b 2012 ABCA 30]
 Similarly, where a judge wishes to impose a condition that was not contemplated by either party nor could it have been easily foreseen, then the judge should also provide notice before doing so. R v Beal, [http://canlii.ca/t/2fk7g 2011 ABCA 35] '''Other Issues'''
Where the accused misapprehended the joint recommendation, it can be grounds for a successful appeal of a sentence. e.g. R v Kinney, [http://www.canlii.org/en/sk/skca/doc/2011/2011skca122/2011skca122.html 2011 SKCA 122] Where an offender is unaware of a significant consequence of a particular sentence agreed upon, such as deportation without appeal, the court may reopen the consideration of sentence.R. v. Jamieson, [http://canlii.ca/t/fpf0n 2011 NSCA 122] {{reflist|2}} ==Repudiating a Plea Bargain== If the Crown renegs on a plea deal on sentence, the Defence may make application to withdraw the guilty plea. R. v. M. (R.N.-Z.) 2006 CanLII 32999 (ON S.C.)[http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onsc/doc/2006/2006canlii32999/2006canlii32999.html]
R. v. Chen, 2009 ONCJ 453[http://www.canlii.org/en/on/oncj/doc/2009/2009oncj453/2009oncj453.html]
see also: R. v. Tallon, 2003 CanLII 27268 (ON C.A.) [http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onca/doc/2003/2003canlii27268/2003canlii27268.html] {{reflist|2}} ==Case Digests== * [[Canadian Criminal Sentencing/Cases/Joint Recommendations|Plea Bargains]] {{BookCat}}

==General Principles== It generally preferred that when calculating a global sentence for multiple offences that the sentence be determined before taking into account pre-trial custody. Instead, the ordered sentence should be declared to be reduced for pre-trial custody credit. R. v. Schira, [http://www.canlii.org/en/ab/abca/doc/2004/2004abca369/2004abca369.html 2004 ABCA 369] R. v. Letta, [http://www.canlii.org/en/mb/mbca/doc/2004/2004mbca179/2004mbca179.html 2004 MBCA 179] A failure to take into account remand time is an error of principle.R v Aubin [http://canlii.ca/t/2607r#par2 2009 BCCA 418 at 2] The method of taking into account remand time is to first calculate the total sentence and then deduct an amount of credit based on the amount of time served. R v Orr [http://canlii.ca/t/1vsdv 2008 BCCA 76] at para. 22 On February, 2010, the ''Truth in Sentencing Act'' came into force limiting to circumstances where offenders on remand can get 2 for 1 credit. All offences occurring before that date will still be subject to the old rules of remand credit. Prior to 2010, courts had discretion to grant 2:1 remand credit for time spent in custody. In practice, this was granted in most cases. The addition of s. 719(3.1) required a credit of 1:1 unless justified and with a maximum of 1:1.5 credit for remand time. {{Quotation| s. 719

...

'''Determination of sentence'''
(3) In determining the sentence to be imposed on a person convicted of an offence, a court may take into account any time spent in custody by the person as a result of the offence but the court shall limit any credit for that time to a maximum of one day for each day spent in custody.

'''Exception'''
(3.1) Despite subsection (3), if the circumstances justify it, the maximum is one and one-half days for each day spent in custody unless the reason for detaining the person in custody was stated in the record under subsection 515(9.1) or the person was detained in custody under subsection 524(4) or (8).

'''Reasons'''
(3.2) The court shall give reasons for any credit granted and shall cause those reasons to be stated in the record.

'''Record of proceedings'''
(3.3) The court shall cause to be stated in the record and on the warrant of committal the offence, the amount of time spent in custody, the term of imprisonment that would have been imposed before any credit was granted, the amount of time credited, if any, and the sentence imposed.

...

R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 719; R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 157; 1995, c. 22, s. 6; 2009, c. 29, s. 3. |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec719 CCC] }} Where the offence is one with a mandatory minimum, the court may give remand credit that has the effect of reducing the sentence below the mandatory jail sentence.R v Wust 2000 18
R. v. Arthurs, 2000 SCC 19 at 1
 Circumstances in which enhanced credit have been given include:R. v. Stonefish, 2012 MBCA 116 (CanLII) - summary of circumstances of enhanced credit # Conditions of the remand facilities: ## lack of available programming and counselling e.g., R. v. Haly, 2012 ONSC 2302 (CanLII) -- 1.2:1 time was given
R. v. Mullins (P.E.), 2011 SKQB 478 (CanLII)
R. c. Auger, 2012 QCCQ 568 (CanLII)
 ## frequency of lockdowns during remand e.g. Mullins
R. v. Oates, 2012 ONCJ 461 (CanLII)
c.f. R. v. Sayed, 2012 ONSC 843 (CanLII) ## duration of time in solitary confinement e.g., R. v. Seymour, 2011 BCSC 1682 (CanLII) solitary for his own protection
R. c. Guo, 2011 QCCQ 10469 (CanLII)
 ## other harsh circumstances in the facility such as double bunking, sleeping on floor, violence, etc. e.g., R. v. J.B., 2011 BCPC 158 (CanLII) - double-bunking and exposure to violence
R. v. Clayton, 2012 ABQB 333 (CanLII) - overcrowding, slept on the floor
Auger - no visitors while on remand
 # delay post-trial not attributed to the accused: ## delay due to court scheduling e.g., R. v. Dingwell (D.A.), 2012 PESC 13 (CanLII)
R. v. B.R.S., 2011 ONCJ 484 (CanLII)
R. v. Sabatine, 2012 ONCJ 310 (CanLII) - judge requested further submissions and time spent drafting reasons
 ## request by Court or Crown for a pre-sentence report or Gladue report e.g,. R. v. House (Z.C.) (2012), 319 Nfld. & P.E.I.R. 197 (NL Prov. Ct.)
R. v. Sharkey, 2011 BCSC 1541 (CanLII)
R. v. Mozumdar, 2012 ONCJ 151 (CanLII)
 ## multiple court appearances for the purposes of sentencing e.g., R. v. Przybyla, 2012 ABPC 183 (CanLII)
 # delay due to Crown e.g., R. c. Lefrançois, 2012 QCCQ 5655 (CanLII)
 Enhanced credit will be ''denied'' in circumstances such as: # delay caused by the offender, including where the proceedings are drawn out deliberately. See R. v. Leggo (R.) (2012), 317 Nfld. & P.E.I.R. 252 (NL Prov. Ct.)
R. v. Morris, 2011 ONSC 5206 (CanLII) R v Johnson, 2011 ONCJ 77
J.B.
Sabatine
 {{Reflist|2}} ==Case Digests== * R. v. Sabatine, [http://canlii.ca/t/frfph 2012 ONCJ 310] - partial enhanced remand credit given {{BookCat}}

==Legislation== {{quotation| '''Victim impact statement'''
722. (1) For the purpose of determining the sentence to be imposed on an offender or whether the offender should be discharged pursuant to section 730 in respect of any offence, the court shall consider any statement that may have been prepared in accordance with subsection (2) of a victim of the offence describing the harm done to, or loss suffered by, the victim arising from the commission of the offence.

'''Procedure for victim impact statement'''
(2) A statement referred to in subsection (1) must be :(a) prepared in writing in the form and in accordance with the procedures established by a program designated for that purpose by the lieutenant governor in council of the province in which the court is exercising its jurisdiction; and :(b) filed with the court.

'''Presentation of statement'''
(2.1) The court shall, on the request of a victim, permit the victim to read a statement prepared and filed in accordance with subsection (2), or to present the statement in any other manner that the court considers appropriate.

'''Evidence concerning victim admissible'''
(3) Whether or not a statement has been prepared and filed in accordance with subsection (2), the court may consider any other evidence concerning any victim of the offence for the purpose of determining the sentence to be imposed on the offender or whether the offender should be discharged under section 730.

...

R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 722; 1995, c. 22, s. 6; 1999, c. 25, s. 17(Preamble); 2000, c. 12, s. 95.

'''Copy of statement'''
722.1 The clerk of the court shall provide a copy of a statement referred to in subsection 722(1), as soon as practicable after a finding of guilt, to the offender or counsel for the offender, and to the prosecutor.

1995, c. 22, s. 6; 1999, c. 25, s. 18(Preamble). |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec722 CCC] }} Under [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/rsc-1985-c-c-46/latest/rsc-1985-c-c-46.html#sec722 s. 722(2)], the Court must consider victim impact statements that are submitted to the court. After a finding of guilt, the court is required under [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/rsc-1985-c-c-46/latest/rsc-1985-c-c-46.html#sec722.2 s. 722.2(1)], to inquire whether the victim has been advised of the opportunity to prepare a victim impact statement. {{reflist|2}} ==Persons Who can File a VIS== Only a victim may file a VIS. Section 722(4) defines a victim as: {{quotation| '''Definition of “victim”'''
(4) For the purposes of this section and section 722.2, “victim”, in relation to an offence, :(a) means a person to whom harm was done or who suffered physical or emotional loss as a result of the commission of the offence; and :(b) where the person described in paragraph (a) is dead, ill or otherwise incapable of making a statement referred to in subsection (1), includes the spouse or common-law partner or any relative of that person, anyone who has in law or fact the custody of that person or is responsible for the care or support of that person or any dependant of that person.

R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 722; 1995, c. 22, s. 6; 1999, c. 25, s. 17(Preamble); 2000, c. 12, s. 95. |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec722 CCC] }} The victim must also be capable of "describing the harm done to, or loss suffered by, the victim arising from the commission of the offence."(s. 722(1)) It has been recommended that VIS not be permitted in by persons who are "unidentified in their connection to the [victim] or too remote in connection".Gabriel at para.48 ==Form of Statement== It has been suggested that in order for a VIS to be admissible it should contain the following: R. v. Gabriel (1999), 137 C.C.C. (3d) 1 (Ont. Sup. Ct.) at para. 16 *the statement is to be prepared in writing, *the statement is to be in the form and in accordance with procedures established by a program designated for that purpose by the province, *the statement is to be authored by a person meeting the definition of "victim" (s. 722(4) of the Code), *the statement is to describe the harm done to, or loss suffered by, the victim arising from the commission of the offence, *the statement is to be filed with the Court, *the clerk of the Court is to provide a copy of the statement to the prosecution and the defence (s. 722.1 of the Code) It is important that when considering the VIS that the court maintain its “independent neutrality" by not "react[ing] to public opinion as to the severity of sentences." Gabriel at para. 33 {{reflist|2}} ==Admissible Content== Impact statements should describe "the harm done to, or loss suffered by, the victim arising from the commission of the offence". (s. 722(1)) ==Inappropriate Content for a VIS== The Statement should describe the harm arising out of the offence. It is not an opportunity for the victim to criticize the offender, including his character, assert facts or recommend sentence. Such comments are inadmissible.R. v. Gabriel, 1999 CanLII 15050 (ON S.C.) 137 C.C.C. (3d) 1 at para. 16
R. v. Bremner, 2000 BCCA 345 at 27 Nor should there be reference to offences not charged.R. v. Noor, 2011 BCSC 1629 at 21 There is limited cases where sentence recommendation may be admissible, such as during a sentencing circle.Gabriel at para. 29 to 33 It has been suggested the follow sort of statements not be permitted:Gabriel at para. 48 to 53 # statements by persons with unidentified connections to the victim or to remote a connection # references to facts that are not accurate # statements speaking of the offender including charactere.g.R. v. Walchuk, [2001] S.J. No. 148 (Sask.C.A.) # suggesting penalties # seeks personal revenge R. v. Bremner [2000] B.C.J. No. 1096 (B.C.C.A), R. v. Sangha, [2001] A.J. No. 545 (Alta. Q.B.), R. v. D.M.L.G. [2001], S.J. No. 581 (Sask. Prov. Ct.), R. v. Hawley [1999] O.J. No. 5393 # promoting an "eye for an eye" # statements that are inflammatory and jeopardize the desired restraint in sentencingR. v. Bremner [2000] B.C.J. No. 1096 (B.C.C.A) calls offender a pedophile # makes diagnoses of the offenderR. v. Bremner [2000] B.C.J. No. 1096 (B.C.C.A) calls him a pedophile # mischaracterizations of the offence or the law {{reflist|2}} ==Offence Specific Impact Statement== {{quotation| '''Community impact statement'''
380.4 (1) For greater certainty, for the purpose of determining the sentence to be imposed on an offender, or whether the offender should be discharged under section 730, in respect of an offence referred to in subsection 380(1), the court may consider a statement made by a person on a community’s behalf describing the harm done to, or losses suffered by, the community arising from the commission of the offence.

'''Procedure'''
(2) The statement must :(a) be prepared in writing and filed with the court; :(b) identify the community on whose behalf the statement is made; and :(c) explain how the statement reflects the community’s views.

'''Copy of statement'''
(3) The clerk of the court shall provide a copy of the statement, as soon as practicable after a finding of guilt, to the offender or counsel for the offender, and to the prosecutor.

2011, c. 6, s. 4. |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec380.4 CCC] }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{BookCat}}

==Guilty plea or Conviction== A sentencing hearing is to be commenced "as soon as practicable" after the point where a conviction has been entered.Section 720(1) {{reflist|2}} ==Submissions of counsel== Both the Crown and Defence are permitted to make submissions to facts for consideration.s. 723(1); R. v. Digiacomo, 2002 BCCA 444 However, submissions themselves do not constitute evidence. R. v. Jackman, [1996] N.J. No. 107 (NLCA) “cannot be over-emphasized that, in making submissions to Court, counsel are not giving evidence but rather making argument in support of their respective submissions.” {{reflist|2}} ==Accused addressing the Court== At the end of the submissions by counsel, the accused is entitled to make comments to the court.s. 726 Failure to allow the accused to speak will not invalidate the sentence if it is an inadvertent slip or error. R. v. Senek (1998), 130 C.C.C. (3d) 473 (Man. C.A.)[http://www.canlii.org/en/mb/mbca/doc/1998/1998canlii17680/1998canlii17680.html]
R. v. Holub and Kufrin, [2002] O.J. No. 579 (Q.L.).
R. v. Haug 2002 SKCA 49 {{reflist|2}} ==Judgement on Sentence== A judge, in deciding on a sentence, after hearing the recommendations from both Crown and Defence, may go above the range recommended by Crown counsel, but must do so after giving reasons for the sentence given. R. v. Jones, [http://canlii.ca/t/fsqtm 2012 ONCA 609] (CanLII) at para. 10 It is also recommended that the judge give counsel an opportunity to make further submissions. see R v Hood, 2011 ABCA 169 (CanLII) at para 15
R v Keough, 2012 ABCA 14 (CanLII) at paras 19 to 20 and 51 to 57
 Upon deciding on a particular sentence the judge shall comply with s.570 and 806 requiring him to make a minute or memorandum of conviction and upon request, make a conviction order under Form 35 or 36. Further a warrant of committal, if applicable, will be made under Form 21 or 22. {{reflist|2}} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Canadian Criminal Sentencing/Available Sentences/Maximum and Minimum Sentences

revision.text:
==Statutory Minimum== It has been agreed upon by several courts that mandatory minimums act as an "inflationary floor" and sets a new minimum punishment for the best offender. R. v. Morrisey, 2000 SCC 39 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/2000/2000scc39/2000scc39.html], discussed in minority decision
R. v. Colville, 2005 ABCA 319 at paras. 21-26 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ab/abca/doc/2005/2005abca319/2005abca319.html]
R. v. Ferguson, 2006 ABCA 261 at para. 85
R. v. B.C.M., 2008 BCCA 365 [http://www.canlii.org/en/bc/bcca/doc/2008/2008bcca365/2008bcca365.html]
R. v. Newman, 2009 NLCA 32 ==Statutory Maximums== The maximum available sentence for a given offence will be provided within the provisions defining the offence. Given the distinction between summary offences and indictable offences, the maximum penalties for summary offences will always be less than indictable. Where an offence is punishable by "summary conviction", [http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec787 section 787(1)] states the punishment will be a fine of no more than $5,000 and/or 6 months jail unless the offence specifies otherwise. Other available summary offence maximums include 18 months jail.e.g. s. 253, 264.1 However, under [http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec735 s. 735] where the accused is an organization, the summary conviction fine amount increases to $100,000. The maximum for indictable offences will always be specified in the provisions. The code will specify a maximum of 2, 5, 10, 14 years jail or life. It is generally stated that the maximum penalty is not simply reserved for the "worst of the worst" offenders.R. v. Solowan, 2008 SCC 62, [2008] 3 S.C.R. 309 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/2008/2008scc62/2008scc62.html]; R. v. L.M., 2008 SCC 31, [2008] 2 S.C.R. 163 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/2008/2008scc31/2008scc31.html] All relevant factors must be considered and should only be consdered appropriate where the "offence is of sufficient gravity and the offender displays sufficient blameworthiness".R. v. Cheddesingh,2004 SCC 16, [2004] 1 S.C.R. 433 [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/2004/2004scc16/2004scc16.html] On summary elections for hybrid offences, the court is bound by the maximum range set by parliament. However, the courts should not "scale up" or "scale down" the sentences due to the election.R. v. Solowan, ''supra'' ==References== {{reflist}} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Canadian Criminal Sentencing/Available Sentences/Concurrent and Consecutive Sentences

revision.text:
==General Principles== Cumulative punishments are known as consecutive sentences. This only applies to jail sentences, all other sentences run concurrently. All sentences are presumed to be served concurrently. The Code provides for cumulative punishments at section 718.3: {{quotation| 718.3

...

'''Cumulative punishments'''
(4) The court or youth justice court that sentences an accused may direct that the terms of imprisonment that are imposed by the court or the youth justice court or that result from the operation of subsection 734(4) or 743.5(1) or (2) shall be served consecutively, when :(a) the accused is sentenced while under sentence for an offence, and a term of imprisonment, whether in default of payment of a fine or otherwise, is imposed; :(b) the accused is found guilty or convicted of an offence punishable with both a fine and imprisonment and both are imposed; :(c) the accused is found guilty or convicted of more than one offence, and ::(i) more than one fine is imposed, ::(ii) terms of imprisonment for the respective offences are imposed, or ::(iii) a term of imprisonment is imposed in respect of one offence and a fine is imposed in respect of another offence; or :(d) subsection 743.5(1) or (2) applies.

1995, c. 22, s. 6; 1997, c. 18, s. 141; 2002, c. 1, s. 182. |[http://canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/rsc-1985-c-c-46/latest/rsc-1985-c-c-46.html#sec718.3 CCC] }} Generally, sentences for offences that occur at separate occasions will be served consecutively. R. v. Dube 2006 QCCA 699 [http://www.canlii.org/fr/qc/qcca/doc/2006/2006qcca699/2006qcca699.html]; R. v. Howett (1982) BCCA While where the offences arise out of the same transaction, the sentences will be typically concurrent. R. v. Mascarenhas, 2002 CanLII 41625 (ON CA) [http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onca/doc/2002/2002canlii41625/2002canlii41625.html];
R. v. Veysey, 2006 NBCA 55 [http://www.canlii.org/en/nb/nbca/doc/2006/2006nbca55/2006nbca55.html]
R. v. Desmarest (1986), 2 Q.A.C. 151
R. v. Charchuk (1973), 6 N.S.R. (2d) 519 If the court does not indicate whether sentences are concurrent or consecutive it is presumed concurrent.R. v. McCarthy 2005 NLCA __ Nevertheless, the decision of consecutive sentences is one entitled to deference.R. v. M.(T.E.), [1997] 1 S.C.R. 948, at para. 46 Sentences may be imposed consecutively in relation to a single transaction where the punishments protect "different societal interests" or "different legal interests".R. v. Gillis, 2009 ONCA 312 [http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onca/doc/2009/2009onca312/2009onca312.html]; R. v. Clarke (1994), 94 CCC 249(NSCA) A judge should consider the time frame within which the offences occurred, the similarity of the offences, whether a new intent or impulse initiated each of the offences and whether the total sentence is fit and proper under the circumstances. R. v. G.A.W., (1993), 125 N.S.R. (2d) 312 (NSCA)
R. v. Naugle, 2011 NSCA 33 When deciding whether a sentence should be consecutive or concurrent, the court should consider 1) the time frame of the offences, 2) the similarity of the offences, 3) whether a new intent broached each offence, and 4) whether the total sentence is fit and proper. R. v. G.A.W., (1993), 125 N.S.R. (2d) 312 (NSCA);
R. v. Naugle, 2011 NSCA 33 (CanLII), 2011 NSCA 33 Certain sentences must be ordered to be served consecutively: #Commission of indictable offence to advantage a terrorist group (s. 83.2 and s. 83.26) #Instructing activity for terrorist group (s. 83.21(1) and s. 83.26) #Instructing terrorist activity (s. 83.22(1) and s. 83.26) #Instructing commission of offence for criminal organization (s. 467.13(1) and s. 467.14) The decision on whether a sentence should be concurrent or consecutive "should be treated with the same deference owed by appellate courts to sentencing judges concerning the length of sentences ordered." R. v. McDonnell, 1997 CanLII 389 (SCC), [1997] 1 S.C.R. 948 at para. 17 {{reflist|2}} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with "== Retrospective punishments == Section 11(i) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedom states: {{quotation|11. Any person charged with an offence has the right ... :(i) ..."
revision.text:
== Retrospective punishments == Section 11(i) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedom states: {{quotation|11. Any person charged with an offence has the right ... :(i) if found guilty of the offence and if the punishment for the offence has been varied between the time of commission and the time of sentencing, to the benefit of the lesser punishment.}} ''Ex post facto'' treatment of the offender is not viewed as punishment under s. 11(i). That includes deportation following convictionsee Re Gittens and the Queen [1983] 1 FC 152, 68 CCC 2d 438 (FCTD); Hurd v. Canada (MEI) [1989] 2 FC 594 (FCA);
 and license suspension under provincial law which is considered a "civil disability"see Johnston v. Superintendent of Motor Vehicles [1987] BCJ No44 (BCSC). === SOIRA Orders=== SOIRA legislation is not considered a "punishment" within the meaning of s. 11(i) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms except where the impact of the order amounts to "harsh treatment".R. v. Cross 2006 NSCA 30 [http://canlii.ca/en/ns/nsca/doc/2006/2006nsca30/2006nsca30.html] at 85 As such, the dominant line of cases suggests that the provisions of SOIRA are retrospective. R. v. Cross, supra
R .v. Aberdeen, [2005] AJ No. 1062 [http://canlii.org/en/ab/abpc/doc/2005/2005abpc203/2005abpc203.html]
R. v. Rouschop == Cruel and Unusual Punishment == Section 12 of the Charter states: "Everyone has the right not to be subjected to any cruel and unusual treatment or punishment." ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{BookCat}}

{{#if:{{{1|}}}|[http://www.youtube.com/embed/{{{1}}} {{{2|http://www.youtube.com/embed/{{{1}}}}}}][[File:LogoYoutube2011.svg|32px|link=http://www.youtube.com/embed/{{{1}}}|alt={{{3|{{{2||http://www.youtube.com/embed/{{{1}}}}}}}}}]]|[[Category:Pages with broken links]]}} {{Documentation}}

== Symmetric groups ==
'''Theorem 1:''' Let <math>A</math> be any set. Then, the set <math>S_A</math> of bijections from <math>A</math> to itself, <math>f\,:,A\rightarrow A</math>, form a group under composition of functions.
''Proof'': We have to verify the group axioms. Associativity is fulfilled since composition of functions is always associative: <math>(f\circ g)\circ h(x) = f\circ g(h(x))=f(g(h(x)))=f(g\circ h(x))=f\circ(g\circ h)(x)</math> where the composition is defined. The identity element is the identity function given by <math>\mathrm{id}_A(a)=a</math> for all <math>a\in A</math>. Finally, the inverse of a function <math>f</math> is the function <math>f^{-1}</math> taking <math>f(a)</math> to <math>a</math> for all <math>a\in A</math>. This function exists and is unique since <math>f</math> is a bijection. Thus <math>S_A</math> is a group, as stated. {{Unicode|∎}}
<math>S_A</math> is called ''the symmetric group on <math>A</math>''. When <math>A=\{1,2,...,n\}\,,\, n\in \mathbb{N}</math>, we write its symmetric group as <math>S_n</math>, and we call this group the ''symmetric group on <math>n</math> letters''. It is also called the group of ''permutations'' on <math>n</math> letters. As we will see shortly, this is an appropriate name.
Instead of <math>e</math>, we will use a different symbol, namely <math>\iota</math>, for the identity function in <math>S_n</math>.
When <math>\sigma\in S_n</math>, we can specify <math>\sigma</math> by specifying where it sends each element. There are many ways to encode this information mathematically. One obvious way is to indentify <math>\sigma</math> as the unique <math>n\times n</math> matrix with value <math>1</math> in the entries <math>(i,\sigma(i))</math> and <math>0</math> elsewhere. Composition of functions then corresponds to multiplication of matrices. Indeed, the matrix corresponding to <math>\rho</math> has value <math>1</math> in the entries <math>(i,\rho(i))</math>, which is the same as <math>(\sigma(j),\rho(\sigma(j)))</math>, so the product has value <math>1</math> in the entries <math>(j,\rho(\sigma(j)))</math>. This notation may seem cumbersome. Luckily, there exists a more convenient notation, which we will make use of.
We can represent any <math>\sigma\in S_n</math> by a <math>2\times n</math> matrix <math>\left( \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 2 & \dots & n \\ \sigma(1) & \sigma(2) & \dots & \sigma(n)\end{array}\right)</math>. We obviously lose the correspondence between function composition and matrix multiplication, but we gain a more readable notation. For the time being, we will use this.
'''Remark 2:''' Let <math>\sigma,\rho\in S_n</math>. Then the product <math>\sigma\rho \equiv \sigma \circ \rho</math> is the function obtained by ''first'' acting with <math>\rho</math>, and ''then'' by <math>\sigma</math>. That is, <math>\sigma\rho(x)=\sigma (\rho (x))</math>. This point is important to keep in mind when computing products in <math>S_n</math>. Some textbooks try to remedy the frequent confusion by writing functions like <math>(x)\rho\sigma</math>, that is, writing arguments on the ''left'' of functions. We will ''not'' do this, as it is not standard. The reader should use the next example and theorem to get a feeling for products in <math>S_n</math>.
'''Example 3:''' We will show the multiplication table for <math>S_3</math>. We introduce the special notation for <math>S_3</math>: <math>\iota=\rho_0</math> <math>\rho_1=\left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & 1 \end{array} \right)</math>, <math>\rho_2=\left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{array} \right)</math>, <math>\mu_1 = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 3 & 2 \end{array} \right)</math>, <math>\mu_2= \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 & 1 \end{array} \right)</math> and <math>\mu_3=\left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{array} \right)</math>. The multiplication table for <math>S_3</math> is then
:<math>\begin{array}{c|cccccc} \circ & \rho_0 & \rho_1 & \rho_2 & \mu_1 & \mu_2 & \mu_3 \\ \hline \rho_0 & \rho_0 & \rho_1 & \rho_2 & \mu_1 & \mu_2 & \mu_3 \\ \rho_1 & \rho_1 & \rho_2 & \rho_0 & \mu_3 & \mu_1 & \mu_2 \\ \rho_2 & \rho_2 & \rho_0 & \rho_1 & \mu_2 & \mu_3 & \mu_1 \\ \mu_1 & \mu_1 & \mu_2 & \mu_3 & \rho_0 & \rho_2 & \rho_1 \\ \mu_2 & \mu_2 & \mu_3 & \mu_1 & \rho_1 & \rho_0 & \rho_2 \\ \mu_3 & \mu_3 & \mu_1 & \mu_2 & \rho_2 & \rho_1 & \rho_0 \end{array}</math>
'''Theorem 4:''' <math>S_n</math> has order <math>n!</math>.
''Proof'': This follows from a counting argument. We can specify a unique element in <math>S_n</math> by specifying where each <math>i\in\{1,2,...,n\}</math> is sent. Also, any permutation can be specified this way. Let <math>\sigma\in S_n</math>. In choosing <math>\sigma(1)</math> we are completely free and have <math>n</math> choices. Then, when choosing <math>\sigma(2)</math> we must choose from <math>\{1,...,n\}-\{\sigma(1)\}</math>, giving a total of <math>n-1</math> choices. Continuing in this fashion, we see that for <math>\sigma(i)</math> we must choose from <math>\{1,...,n\}-\{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(i-1)\}</math>, giving a total of <math>n+1-i</math> choices. The total number of ways in which we can specify an element, and thus the number of elements in <math>S_n</math> is then <math>|S_n|=\prod_{i=1}^n (n+1-i)=n(n-1)...\cdot 2 \cdot 1 = n!</math>, as was to be shown. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 5:''' <math>S_n</math> is non-abelian for all <math>n\geq 3</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>\sigma=\left( \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & \dots & n \\ 2 & 1 & 3 & \dots & n\end{array}\right)</math> be the function only interchanging 1 and 2, and <math>\rho=\left( \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & \dots & n \\ 1 & 3 & 2 & \dots & n\end{array}\right)</math> be the function only interchanging 2 and 3. Then <math>\sigma \rho = \left( \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & \dots & n \\ 2 & 3 & 1 & \dots & n\end{array}\right)</math> and <math>\rho\sigma = \left( \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & \dots & n \\ 3 & 1 & 2 & \dots & n\end{array}\right)</math>. Since <math>\sigma\rho \neq \rho \sigma</math>, <math>S_n</math> is not abelian. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Definition 6:''' Let <math>\sigma\in S_n</math> such that <math>\sigma^n=\iota</math> for some <math>n\in \mathbb{Z}</math>. Then <math>\sigma</math> is called an <math>n</math>''-cycle'', where <math>n</math> is the smallest positive such integer. Let <math>\sigma^*</math> be the set of integers <math>a</math> such that <math>\sigma(a)\neq a</math>. Two cycles <math>\sigma,\rho</math> are called ''disjoint'' if <math>\sigma^*\cap \rho^* = \emptyset</math>. Also, a 2-cycle is called a ''transposition''.
'''Theorem 7:''' Let <math>\sigma,\rho\in S_n</math>. If <math>\sigma^*\cap \rho^*=\emptyset</math>, then <math>\sigma\rho=\rho\sigma</math>.
''Proof'': For any integer <math>1\leq a\leq n</math> such that <math>a\in \sigma^*</math> but <math>a\not\in\rho^*</math> we have <math>\sigma\rho(a)=\sigma(\iota(a))=\sigma(a)=\iota(\sigma(a))=\rho(\sigma(a))=\rho\sigma(a)</math>. A similar argument holds for <math>a\in \rho^*</math> but <math>a\not\in\sigma^*</math>. If <math>a\not\in\sigma^*\cup\rho^*</math>, we must have <math>\sigma\rho(a)=\sigma(a)=a=\rho(a)=\rho\sigma(a)</math>. Since <math>\sigma^*\cap\rho^*=\emptyset</math>, we have now exhausted every <math>a\in \{1,...,n\}</math>, and we are done. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 8:''' Any permutation can be represented as a composition of disjoint cycles.
''Proof'': Let <math>\sigma\in S_n</math>. Choose an element <math>a\in \sigma^*</math> and compute <math>\sigma(a),\sigma^2(a),...,\sigma^k(a)=a</math>. Since <math>S_n</math> is finite of order <math>n!</math>, we know that <math>k</math> exists and <math>k \leq n!</math>. We have now found a <math>k</math>-cycle <math>\sigma_1</math> including <math>a</math>. Since <math>\sigma_1^* = \{a,\sigma(a),...,\sigma^{k-1}(a)\}</math>, this cycle may be factored out <math>\sigma</math>, obtaining <math>\sigma=\sigma_1\sigma^\prime</math>. Repeat this process, which terminates since <math>\sigma^*</math> is finite, and we have contructed a composition of disjoint cycles which equal <math>\sigma</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
Now that we have shown that all permuations are just compositions of disjoint cycles, we can introduce the ultimate shorthand notation for permutations. For an <math>n</math>-cycle <math>\sigma</math>, we can show its action by choosing any element <math>a\in\sigma^*</math> and writing <math>\sigma=\left(a\ \sigma(a)\ \sigma^{2}(a)\ ...\ \sigma^{n-1}(a)\right)</math>.
'''Theorem 9:''' Any <math>n</math>-cycle can be represented as a composition of transpositions.
''Proof'': Let <math>\sigma=\left(a\ \sigma(a)\ \sigma^{2}(a)\ ...\ \sigma^{n-1}(a)\right)</math>. Then, <math>\sigma = \left( a\ \sigma^2(a)\ ...\ \sigma^{n-1}(a)\right)\left(a\ \sigma(a)\right)</math> (check this!), omitting the composition sign <math>\circ</math>. Interate this process to obtain <math>\sigma=\left(a\ \sigma^{n-1}(a)\right)...\left(a\ \sigma^{2}(a)\right)\left(a\ \sigma(a)\right)</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Note 10:''' This way of representing <math>\sigma</math> as a product of transpositions is ''not'' unique. However, as we will see now, the "parity" of such a representation is well defined.
'''Definition 11:''' The ''parity'' of a permutation is ''even'' if it can be expressed as a product of an even number of transpositions. Otherwise, it is ''odd''. We define the function <math>\sgn(\sigma)=1</math> if <math>\sigma</math> is even and <math>\sgn(\sigma)=-1</math> if <math>\sigma</math> is odd.
'''Lemma 12:''' The indentity <math>\iota</math> has even parity.
''Proof'': Observe first that <math>\iota \neq (a\ b)</math> for <math>a\neq b</math>. Thus the minimum number of transpositions neccesary to represent <math>\iota</math> is 2: <math>\iota=(a\ b)(a\ b)</math>. Now, assume that for any representation using less than <math>k</math> transpositions must be even. Thus, let <math>\iota=(a_1\ b_1)...(a_k\ b_k)</math>. Now, since in paticular <math>\iota(a_1)=a_1</math>, we must have <math>a_1\in (a_i\ b_i)^*</math> for some <math>1<i\leq k</math>. Since disjoint transpositions commute, and <math>(a_r\ a_s)(a_i\ a_r)=(a_i\ a_s)(a_r\ a_s)</math> where <math>a_i\neq a_r\neq a_s</math>, it is always possible to configure the transpositions such that the first two transpositions are either <math>(a_1\ b_1)(a_1\ b_1)=\iota</math>, reducing the number of transposition by two, or <math>(a_1\ b_1)(a_1\ b_2)=(a_1\ b_2)(b_1\ b_2)</math>. In this case we have reduced the number of transpositions involving <math>a_1</math> by 1. We restart the same process as above. with the new representation. Since only a finite number of transpositions move <math>a_1</math>, we will eventually be able to cancel two permutations and be left with <math>k-2</math> transpositions in the product. Then, by the induction hypothesis, <math>k-2</math> must be even and so <math>k</math> is even as well, proving the lemma. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 13:''' The parity of a permutation, and thus the <math>\sgn</math> function, is well-defined.
''Proof'': Let <math>\sigma\in S_n</math> and write <math>\sigma</math> as a product of transposition in two different ways: <math>\sigma=\tau_1...\tau_k=\tau_1^\prime...\tau_{k^\prime}^\prime</math>. Then, since <math>\iota</math> has even parity by Lemma 11 and <math>\iota = \sigma\sigma^{-1} = \tau_1...\tau_k\tau_{k^\prime}^\prime ... \tau_1^\prime</math>. Thus, <math>k+k^\prime \equiv 0 \ \mathrm{mod}\ 2</math>, and <math>k\equiv k^\prime\ \mathrm{mod}\ 2</math>, so <math>\sigma</math> has a uniquely defined parity, and consequentially <math>\sgn</math> is well-defined. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 14:''' Let <math>\sigma,\rho\in S_n</math>. Then, <math>\sgn(\sigma\rho)=\sgn(\sigma)\sgn(\rho)</math>.
''Proof'': Decompose <math>\sigma</math> and <math>\rho</math> into transpositions: <math>\sigma=\mu_1...\mu_k</math>, <math>\rho=\nu_1...\nu_l</math>. Then <math>\sigma\rho=\mu_1...\mu_k\nu_1...\nu_l</math> has parity given by <math>k+l</math>. If both are even or odd, <math>k+l</math> is even and indeed <math>\sgn(\sigma)\sgn(\rho)=1\cdot 1=1=\sgn(\sigma\rho)</math>. If one is odd and one is even, <math>k+l</math> is odd and again <math>\sgn(\sigma)\sgn(\rho)=(-1)\cdot 1=-1=\sgn(\sigma\rho)</math>, proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Lemma 15:''' The number of even permutations in <math>S_n</math> equals the number of odd permutations.
''Proof'': Let <math>\sigma</math> be any even permutation and <math>\tau</math> a transposition. Then <math>\tau\sigma</math> has odd parity by Theorem 14. Let <math>E</math> be the set of even permutations and <math>O</math> the set of odd permutations. Then the function <math>f:E\rightarrow O</math> given by <math>f(\sigma)=\tau\sigma</math> for any <math>\sigma\in E</math> and a fixed transposition <math>\tau</math>, is a bijection. (Indeed, it is a transposition in <math>S_{S_n}</math>!) Thus <math>E</math> and <math>O</math> have the same number of elements, as stated. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Definition 16:''' Let the set of all even permutations in <math>S_n</math> be denoted by <math>A_n</math>. <math>A_n</math> is called the ''alternating group'' on <math>n</math> letters.
'''Theorem 17:''' <math>A_n</math> ''is'' a group, and is a subgroup of <math>S_n</math> of order <math>\frac{n!}{2}</math>.
''Proof'': We first show that <math>A_n</math> is a group under composition. Then it is automatically a subgroup of <math>S_n</math>. That <math>A_n</math> is closed under composition follows from Theorem 14 and associativity is inherited from <math>S_n</math>. Also, the identity permutation is even, so <math>\iota\in A_n</math>. Thus <math>A_n</math> is a group and a subgroup of <math>S_n</math>. Since the number of even and odd permutations are equal by Lemma 14, we then have that <math>|A_n|=\frac{|S_n|}{2}=\frac{n!}{2}</math>, proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 18:''' Let <math>n\geq 3</math>. Then <math>A_n</math> is generated by the 3-cycles in <math>S_n</math>.
''Proof'': We must show that any even permutation can be decomposed into 3-cycles. It is sufficient to show that this is the case for pairs of transpositions. Let <math>a,b,c,d\in S_n</math> be distinct. Then, by some casework,
:i) <math>(a\ b)(a\ b)=(a\ b\ c)^3</math>,
:ii) <math>(a\ b)(b\ c)=(c\ a\ b)</math>, and
:iii) <math>(a\ b)(c\ d)=(a\ d\ c)(a\ b\ c)</math>,
proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
In a previous section we proved Lagrange's Theorem: The order of any subgroup divides the order of the parent group. However, the converse statement, that a group has a subgroup for every divisor of its order, is false! The smallest group providing a counterexample is the alternating group <math>A_4</math>, which has order 12 but no subgroup of order 6. It has subgroups of orders 3 and 4, corresponding respectively to the cyclic group of order 3 and the Klein 4-group. However, if we add any other element to the subgroup corresponding to <math>C_3</math>, it generates the whole group <math>A_4</math>. We leave it to the reader to show this.
== Dihedral Groups ==
[[File:Hexagon Reflections.png|thumb|The lines represent the reflection symmetries of a regular hexagon]] [[File:Dihedral8.png|thumb|Illustration of the elements of the dihedral group <math>D_{16}</math> as rotations and reflections of a stop sign.]] The dihedral groups are the symmetry groups of regular polygons. As such, they are subgroups of the symmetric groups. In general, a regular <math>n</math>-gon has <math>n</math> rotational symmetries and <math>n</math> reflection symmetries. The dihedral groups capture these by consisting of the associated rotations and reflections.
'''Definition 19:''' The ''dihedral group of order ''<math>2n</math>, denoted <math>D_{2n}</math>, is the group of rotations and reflections of a regular <math>n</math>-gon.
'''Theorem 20:''' The order of <math>D_{2n}</math> is precisely <math>2n</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>\rho</math> be a rotation that generates a subgroup of order <math>n</math> in <math>D_{2n}</math>. Obviously, <math>\langle\rho\rangle</math> then captures all the pure rotations of a regular <math>n</math>-gon. Now let <math>\mu</math> be any rotation in The rest of the elements can then be found by composing each element in <math>\langle\rho\rangle</math> with <math>\mu</math>. We get a list of elements <math>D_{2n}=\{ \iota,\rho,...,\rho^{n-1},\mu,\mu\rho,...,\mu\rho^{n-1}\}</math>. Thus, the order of <math>D_{2n}</math> is <math>2n</math>, justifying its notation and proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Remark 21:''' From this proof we can also see that <math>\{\rho,\mu\}</math> is a generating set for <math>G</math>, and all elements can be obtained by writing arbitrary products of <math>\rho</math> and <math>\mu</math> and simplifying the expression according to the rules <math>\rho^n=\iota</math>, <math>\mu^2=\iota</math> and <math>\rho\mu=\mu\rho^{-1}</math>. Indeed, as can be seen from the figure, a rotation composed with a reflection is new reflection.
{{BookCat}}

Notes on Chapter: *cases **monkey drug trials **polio testing, Salk **AIDS research (tenofovir)
Other Notes: *500 words (max) per case *300-500 words for intro and conclusion *4 minutes per case for presentation *possible introduction: list common products produced from non-human primate testing, connect these with audience *possible introduction: run through taxonomy of animals and ask where the ethical testing line is
Cases: *background *ethical discussion *relevant social groups
Possible Sources *http://www.iep.utm.edu/anim-eth/ *A quick Google search reveals many articles *[[w:Animal_Welfare_Act_of_1966|Animal Welfare Act of 1966]]
Relevant Groups *PETA *National Anti-Vivisection Society: http://www.navs.org *Humane Society of the United States: http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/biomedical_research/
"Speciesism" *penned by Richard Ryder: http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2005/aug/06/animalwelfare *the fundamental counterargument: Cohen, C.(1986). The case for the use of animals in biomedical research. ''New England Journal of Medicine'', 315(14). http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198610023151405
Case Study: Great Ape Research Ban *Great Ape Protection and Cost Savings Act of 2011 introduced April 13, 2011: http://thomas.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c112:H.R.1513: *Use of primates in research worldwide: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15300710 *Great Ape "personhood": http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/6505691.stm

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Kyung.choi!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!

Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Ronaldoh1!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''! [[User:Ronaldoh1|Ronaldoh1]] ([[User talk:Ronaldoh1|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ronaldoh1|contribs]]) 12:20, 28 April 2012 (UTC)

page.title: A-level Computing/AQA/Problem Solving, Programming, Data Representation and Practical Exercise/Problem Solving/Structure charts

revision.comment: Rejected the last 8 text changes (by [[Special:Contributions/178.78.109.50|178.78.109.50]]) and restored revision 2469634 by Pluke
revision.text:
{{CPTPageNavigationU1| | Prev = Top-down design and Step-wise refinement | Next = Decision tables}} {{displaytitle|title=Problem Solving: Structure Charts}} [[File:CPT-Structured_Chart_Example.svg|thumb|center|350px|Structure charts can map the structure and data flow of complicated tasks]] A Structure Chart in software engineering is a chart which shows the breakdown of a system to its lowest manageable parts. They are used in structured programming to arrange program modules into a tree. Each module is represented by a box, which contains the module's name. The tree structure visualizes the relationships between modules, showing data transfer between modules using arrows. Structured Charts are an example of a '''top-down''' design where a problem (the program) is broken into its components. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Symbol !! Name !! Meaning |- | {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- | Module
Name |} || Process || Each Box represents a programming module, this might be something that calculates the average of some figures, or prints out some pay slips |- | [[File:CPT-Structured Chart Data Couple.svg]] || Data Couple || Data being passed from module to module that needs to be processed. |- | [[File:CPT-Structured Chart Flag.svg]] || Flag || [Extension - you don't need to know this for the exam] Check data sent to process to stop or start processes. For example when the End of a File that is being read is reached, or a flag to say whether data sent was in the correct format |} Let's take a look at a simple example of how this might be executed when representing the following code: dim num1 as integer dim num2 as integer sub calculateAverage() dim avg as integer inputNums() avg = average(num1, num2) outputAvg(avg) end sub function average(a,b) return (a + b) / 2 end function sub inputNums() num1 = console.readline() num2 = console.readline() end sub sub outputAvg(x) console.writeline("average = " & x) end sub [[File:CPT-Structured Chart Average.svg|thumb|400px|center|A structure chart for the above code]] {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Structure Charts}} {{CPTQuestionTab}} Create structure charts for the following code: sub main() dim num1 as integer dim num2 as integer dim avg as integer sayHello() num1 = 34 num2 = 89 avg = average(num1, num2) end sub function average(a,b) return (a + b) / 2 end function sub sayHello() console.writeline("hello") end sub {{CPTQuestionTabEnd}} {{CPTAnswerTab}}[[File:CPT-Structured-Chart-Q1.svg|350px]]{{CPTAnswerTabEnd}} {{Robox/Close}} ====Selection==== [[File:CPT-Structured Chart Selection.svg|thumb|center|200px|Structure Chart representation of the selection code]] A selection in a Structure Chart is determined by the diamond symbol. This means a condition will be checked and depending on the result, different modules will be executed. sub main() dim num1 as integer num1 = console.readline() if num1 = 7 then luckyNumber() else otherNumber() endif end sub ====Iteration==== [[File:CPT-Structured Chart Loop.svg|thumb|center|85px|Structure Chart of the code to the left]] Using the semi circular arrow we can represent iteration in Structure Charts. The arrow encompasses a link to a module, implying that module is executed multiple times. Let's take a look at a coded example: sub main() dim num1 as integer num1 = console.readline() while num1 > 0 do num1 = countdown(num1) end while end sub sub countdown(a) return a - 1 end sub {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Structure Charts, Iteration and Selection}} {{CPTQuestionTab}} Create structure charts for the following code: sub howManyThrees() dim num1, count, total as integer num1 = startMsg() count = 0 total = 0 while num1 > 0 do checkNumber(count, total, num1) num1 = num1 - 1 end while endMsg(count) end sub sub checkNumber(byRef c, byRef t, byVal n) If n MOD 3 = 0 Then c = divBy3(c) Else t = add(n, t) EndIf end sub function divBy3(x) return x + 1 end function function add(n, t) return n + t end function function startMsg() console.writeline("program started, enter your number") return console.readline() end function sub endMsg(n) console.writeline("number of threes : " & n) end sub {{CPTQuestionTabEnd}} {{CPTAnswerTab}}[[File:CPT-Structured-Chart-Q2.svg|500px]]{{CPTAnswerTabEnd}} {{Robox/Close}} {{BookCat}}

page.title: The Computer Revolution/Properly Dispose of Hardware Containing Data

revision.comment: /* Properly Dispose of Hardware Containing Data */
revision.text: ==Properly Dispose of Hardware Containing Data== [[File:Utrecht huisvuil.jpg|left|thumb|proper wasteland]] Protecting the privacy of personal information is very important for both individuals and businesses. Information that individuals and businesses can include tax returns, and passwords for personal websites or social websites, sometimes can include, personal videos pictures, or even music.One key way of doing this is protecting the information located on paper documents and hardware (such as backup media, used CDs, obsolete computers, and mobile phones) that you will be disposing. Papers, CDs, DVDs, and other media containing sensitive data should be shredded. Hard drives should be wiped with special disk-wiping or disk-erasing software before being sold or recycled. Data that has been erased or reformatted can still be recovered so it is best to properly wipe the drive. Physically destroying all of these hardwares is also good so there is no way of getting the important data back and data destruction services are available. Many companies and business do that so no thief or rival can get a hold of their data. Although you can wipe of your hard drive, sometimes be recovered, but many find difficult to do so. By breaking your hard drive, disks, or CD's with a hammer, it is a safer way to do so. Some companies even melt their information and throw it in a fire. A movie i have recently watched "Argo", showed of a U.S base, destroying their files a perfect example of properly disposing their data, informations and hard drives with fire, so the country they were in would not get a hold of their data. [[File:Streichholz.jpg|thumb|fire used to burn hard copies, or melt hard drives]] [[File:Paper Shredder.jpg|left|thumb|Paper Shredder]] {{BookCat}} Source: Understanding Computers Today and Tomorrow Deborah Morley, Charles S.Parker. Chapter 15 pg. 616

revision.text: How do I find out who is the author of this page? I liked what he said and I had a few questions for him/her.

{| style="background-color:#F9F9F9; margin: auto auto auto auto; border:none;" | [[File:Gnome-searchtool.svg|48px|link=]] | style="text-align:center" | '''[[m:CheckUser Policy|CheckUser]] evidence has determined that this [[w:IP address|IP address]], [[w:CIDR range|IP range]], or account has been used abusively.
This address (or network) has been blocked to prevent further abuse.''' |}
In extreme cases, an entire network may be blocked to prevent an abusive user from continually changing their IP address in order to evade blocks or abusing multiple accounts. '''Administrators:''' [[Special:ListUsers/checkuser|CheckUsers]] are privy to confidential system logs not accessible by the public or [[Wikibooks:Administrators|administrators]] due to the Wikimedia Foundation's [[foundation:Privacy_policy|privacy policy]], and therefore '''[http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Administrators%27_noticeboard&diff=101898276&oldid=101897313 must]''' be consulted before this block can be removed. '''Users:''' You may request {{tlx|unblock}} through the normal channels, however a [[Special:ListUsers/checkuser|CheckUser]] will review the block. {{ #if: | ---- '''Comments:''' {{{1}}} : | {{#if:|: {{{sig}}}}} }}

Paleoecology uses fossils and sub fossils to recreate the ecosystems and environments in the past. It involves the study of prehistoric fossils of organisms and remains that have been fossilized. The goal is to be able to recreate the fossils paleoenvironments, life cycle, living interactions, and the death and burial of the fossil. It is then that scientists will be able to see the ecosystems of prehistoric organisms and their environs. {{BookCat}}
