revision.comment: /* Clarified the Demo Database local installation instructions */
revision.text:
= The Demo Database = GNU Health default installation comes with no data. It's interesting, for academic and training purposes to have some demo data that exemplifies concepts and improves the learning curve.
The demo database is an ongoing project and it will be adapting to the each new GNU Health version. The clinical history will also grow with time. For consistency sake, it's important to have the main characters information constant (family members name, birth dates and place, health centers, family doctors ... ). The information and characters are fictitious and we should try to make it valid for different cultures. == The Zenon-Betz Family == The story goes around the Betz family, and the main character, "Ana Betz", a primary school teacher. * Health Center : GNU Solidario Hospital in Las Palmas, Spain * Family Doctor : Cameron Cordara. ID : 765870 . Speciality : Family Medicine . Insitution : GNU Solidario Hospital * Family : Zenon-Betz family : John Zenon (SSN : 40556644 ), Ana Betz and their son, Matt (SSN : 97234436 ). * Ana : The main character. Born October 4th, 1985 .
'''Demographics Information''' * Social Security Number : 55567890 * Sex : Female. * Marital Status : Married * Profession : School teacher. * Education Level : University * Domiciliary Unit ** Housing Conditions :Comfortable and good sanitary conditions '''Patient Information''' * Socio-Economic Status :Middle class * Allergies : β-lactam hypersensitivity * Diseases : Type 1 Diabetes diagnosed on November 10th 1993 . * Medication : Insulin since November 10th 1993 * Genetic Information ** Family history *** Maternal Grandfather : Marfan's Syndrome ( Q87.4 ) *** Father : Essential (primary) hypertension ( I10 ) ** Disease Genes *** BRCA1:breast cancer 1, early onset * Obstetric Information : G1P1A0 ** Newborn : Matt. DoB : March 15th 2010 . Epidural, vaginal birth. * Lifestyle ** Ex-smoker ** Addictions : No recreational drugs ** Sexuality : Heterosexual; Monogamous and practices safe sex. ** Safety : Motorcycle rider. Uses helmet
'''Other Information''' * Family information (Family functionality level, members, operational sectors... ) * Imaging ( X-rays, CTs, MRIs.. ) * Genetic info / risks * Surgeries * Lab orders and results * Clinical history of the family
== The online Demo Database == We have a community server available in the Internet so you can connect and try the latest GNU Health .

First, you need to download and install the Tryton client application, according to your operating system
[http://downloads2.tryton.org/3.0/tryton-3.0.2.tar.gz GNU/Linux]
[http://downloads2.tryton.org/3.0/tryton-setup-3.0.2.exe Windows]
[http://downloads.tryton.org/3.0/tryton-last.dmg MacOS X]

Then you have to set the correct tabs position: [[GNU_Health/Installation#Setting_the_Tryton_client_Tabs_position_for_GNU_Health|Setting the Tryton client Tabs position for GNU Health]]

Finally you can login using the following information:
'''Server''': health.gnusolidario.org:8000
'''Database''': health24
'''User name''': admin
'''Password''': gnusolidario == Installing a local Demo Database == We use the '''proteus''' engine to install the demo database. First we need to install proteus in your local environment $ pip install --user proteus '''Alternatively''', and if you're using any Debian GNU/Linux system, you can also install proteus from a repository. $ apt-get install tryton-proteus '''Warning''', do not install proteus using pip and then apt-get as well. Most likely difference version of proteus will be installed and the demo database installation will fail. Now, look for the demo directory. You can run the script from anywhere, but make sure your tryton libraries are in the python search path. This is important, specially if you use the manual installation. $ export PYTHONPATH="" So, for example, if you installed the GNU Health sever with the standard method, then your variable declaration for PYTHONPATH for Tryton 3.0.3 would be something like : $ export PYTHONPATH="/home/gnuhealth/gnuhealth/tryton/server/trytond-3.0.3/" Next, run the script : $ cd $ python health_demo_server.py So, for example, if you installed the GNU Health sever with the standard method, the demo directory would ~/gnuhealth-2.4.1/scripts/demo (or whatever version number yours is) and you use: $ cd ~/gnuhealth-2.4.1/scripts/demo $ python health_demo_server.py This script will create a new database called '''gnuhealth_demo''' with the demo information. Be patient, it can take some time. User name: admin
Password: admin {{chapnav|Troubleshooting|FAQ}} [[es:GNU Health/Base de datos Demo]] {{BookCat}}

Henry is a person who is interested in things.
Henry fancies himself as an all-rounder, goes under the name of NeoTall at [http://www.deviantart.com/ Deviant Art] for example.

Hello guys!
I want to become a professional Software Engineer(SE) or a Computer Programmer(CP). Some one can lead me in this regard. I mean I want to know which programming languages I must learn to become a good SE or a CP. Here are some questions if some one would like to answer:
# What is an ''Object'' in object oriented languages? # Does C++ can be used in a way like visual basic is used. ( I mean can we provide any GUI like using VB in C++?)

==General Principles== The common law provides for a defence of necessity for "emergency situations where normal human instincts, whether self-preservation or of altruism, overwhelmingly impels disobedience." R v Perka, [1984] 2 S.C.R. 232 The defence provides a legal excuse (as opposed to a justification) for conduct making out the offence.R v Perka, [1984] 2 SCR 232 The defence is to be "strictly controlled and scrupulously limited" to situations of true involuntariness.R v Perka, [1984] 2 SCR 232
R. v. Latimer, 2001 SCC 1, [2001] 1 S.C.R. 3, at paras. 26 to 34 The elements to make out the defence of necessity: # the accused must be in imminent peril or danger See Morgentaler v. The Queen, 1975 CanLII 8, [1976] 1 S.C.R. 616, at p. 678 # the accused must have had no reasonable legal alternative to the course of action he or she undertook # the harm inflicted by the accused must be proportional to the harm avoided by the accused The peril or danger must be more than just foreseeable or likely. It must be near and unavoidable. At the least, "the situation must be so emergent and the peril must be so pressing that normal human instincts cry out for action and make a counsel of patience unreasonable."R v Perka, [1984] 2 SCR 232 To be proportional, the harm avoided must be at least comparable to the harm inflicted. The elements of imminent peril and no alternative is determined on a modified objective standard taking into account the situation and characteristics of the accused.R. v. Latimer, [http://canlii.ca/t/523c 2001 SCC 1], [2001] 1 SCR 3 at 32 to 34 The element of proportionality is measured on an objective standard. The defences first set out in R v Latimer, however, had previously been considered as potentially available in the case of Morgentaler v. The Queen, [1976] 2 S.C.R. 616. {{reflist|2}} ==Case digests== * R v Dirk, [http://canlii.ca/t/fqzkm 2012 SKPC 61] -- impaired driving -- accused drove a few feet in order to avoid person who was smashing his car-not proportionate, or without alternatives * R. v. Valauskas, [http://canlii.ca/t/fvj3m 2012 ONCJ 790] (CanLII) - impaired driving - the accused drove drunk to escape attackers * R. v. Murray, [http://canlii.ca/t/2dtf7 2010 ABQB 784] -- impaired driving charge -- accused co-worked beaten unconscious and a group of angry men threatened to beat him--defence accepted * R v Maragh, [2003] O.J. No. 3574 - flight from police * R v McCain, [2003] O.J. No. 1762 (C.J.) -- Breach of recognizance * R v Burgess, [2003] O.J. No. 4633 (C.J.) -- failing to remain at the scene * R v Sanders, [2001] O.J. No. 2207 -- cultivation -- * R v Hill [1999] B.C.J. No. 933 (Prov.Ct.) -- failing to remain at the scene * R v Gourlay (1996), 182 A.R. 126 (ABPC) - theft * R v Lalonde (1995), 22 O.R. (3d) 275 (Gen.Div.) - fraud - * R v West (1994), 123 Nfld. & P.E.I.R. 234, (NLSC) - impaired driving - successful. accused was driving to corner store to call police to eject a guest * R v Stevenson, [1986] 42 Man.R.(2d) 133 (MBQB) -- mischief * R v Fry (1977), 36 C.C.C.(2d) 396 (SKPC) - dangerous operation - successful {{BookCat}} [[Category:Canadian Criminal Defences|Necessity]]
[[File:Example.jpg]]

page.title: Space Transport and Engineering Methods/Recycling Methods

revision.text: {{DISPLAYTITLE:Section 3.9 - Recycling Methods}} {{TOC right}} Most locations off the Earth do not have automatic recycling of waste products, and a space project will have a finite amount of materials that have been processed beyond the raw state. We define '''Recycling''' as the application of energy and processes to convert materials from a non-useful state back to a useful state. It shares some technology with production from raw materials, except using materials that have already been processed previously and are not in their raw state. In fact some recycling methods will involve feeding waste products back into a production process. ===Waste Recycling=== A goal for recycling is to achieve '''Closure''', where all waste products are converted back to useful states and the only external input is energy. We expect this to be a theoretical limit similar to conversion efficiency in electrical transformers and motors. Those devices can reach 98% efficiency but not 100%. Similarly, practical recycling is expected to reach a high percentage, but not 100%. To the extent your percent closure CL% approaches 100, the amount of new raw materials required is reduced to 100-CL% of an open system with no recycling. So a high percent closure can have a dramatic effect on the need for new raw material processing or replacement items brought from elsewhere. Some items by their nature are not amenable to recycling. A prominent example is reaction mass expelled outside a gravity well by a propulsion method. You are deliberately throwing that mass away in order to get thrust, and outside a gravity well there is no practical way to recover it to use it again. Within a gravity well, such as launching from Earth using a chemical rocket, all the reaction mass is sub-orbital - ranging from about -1/2 orbital velocity to +1/2 orbital velocity depending on the vehicle velocity. Therefore it all ends up back on Earth and can be used again. While some reaction mass cannot be recovered, you can deliberately choose high efficiency methods that lose less mass this way, and use methods such as gravity assist that do not lose propellant mass. ===Closed Loop Life Support=== Humans are biological organisms with certain requirements to continue living, including clean air, water, and sufficient food. They also produce waste products from the human standpoint, such as CO2, urine, and feces. On Earth those wastes from the human standpoint are necessary inputs to plants and other organisms, and solar powered evaporation produces clean water in the form of rain. The natural cycles form closed loops. For space projects we have to replicate the function of those closed loops with artificial systems, or supply air, water, and food from external sources. The more time and the higher the number of humans the greater the outside supply mass becomes, and so the more desirable a closed loop system becomes. Besides inputs such as air, food, and water, humans additionally need controlled lighting, temperature, pressure, radiation levels, and acceleration. Prepared food and feces are complex from a chemical standpoint, there are secondary volatiles and shed skin produced by humans, and body and clothing cleaning are desirable. Therefore a full life support system for humans is complex. We apply the Systems Engineering approach of dividing it into simpler sub-systems that each perform part of the total functions required, and then optimize the full system as a whole. In addition to the direct functions that provide life support, such as growing plants producing food, there are also indirect functions caused by meeting the requirements of the plants, such as water, illumination, gravity, and C02 concentration. The methods listed below include meeting both direct and indirect functions. ====Artificial Gravity==== Humans and plants are evolved in a 1 g environment. Without gravity, human bones deteriorate and some plants may not grow properly. With gravity, water circulation and dust settling operate by familiar methods. If local gravity from a large satellite or planet is not sufficient, artificial acceleration can be generated by rotation. ====Illumination==== Photosynthetic plants need sufficient illumination of the right wavelengths to grow, and humans need sufficient light to see and navigate. Having both evolved on Earth with the Sun as the main source of illumination, both use the wavelength band that the Sun emits the most power at, known as '''Visible Light'''. There are slight differences in intensity, day cycle, and wavelengths for various plants, and for what humans need to see properly. Natural sunlight is easily obtained at many locations in space, so it certainly should be considered if available. Artificial lighting is available for circumstances where natural sunlight is not sufficient, but that usually requires a power source to operate. For a large area of plants that amounts to a lot of power, so natural sources are usually preferred, even if it needs to be concentrated. ====Soil==== Plants on Earth often grow in soil, which is broken down rock plus microorganisms, water, nutrients, and organic matter. Hydroponics dispenses with the inert rock component, which can save mass for space projects. If radiation shielding is required, though, the inert rock component can serve a dual function. While fully developed soils are only known from Earth, there are many sources in space of small rock particles, water, and carbon which make up a large part of soil mass. ====Food==== Human food requirements can be measured in terms of total energy, commonly measured in '''Food Calories''' which are equivalent to 4184 Joules of available energy. The requirements are also measured by a wide variety of specific nutrients in specific amounts. It may not be efficient to supply all the low mass nutrients in a given situation, while supplying the main ones by mass. Whatever nutrients are not obtained from the closed loop system would have to be supplemented from outside, or simply done without for short missions. Human requirements can be translated to specific growing areas per person using known data on agricultural productivity. This data can be modified by designs of space systems. For example, if a plant needs 12 hours of sunlight per day, you can grow twice as much in the same area by using trays that are swapped every 12 hours, and storing the other tray under the illuminated one. {{BookCat}}

Every character must belong to one (or more) character classes. These are Archetypes that describe what role the character performs in the fantasy world. For instance, a Wizard would be heavily focussed on magic, A Fighter on weapons, a Monk on open hand combat etc.
* Fighter * Paladin * Ranger * Barbarian * Cleric * Thief * Wizard * Druid * Monk {{BookCat|filing=deep}}

Using Gold and Silver coins the players decide what their characters need (or can afford) to buy, in order to outfit them for the coming adventures. Weapons, Armour, Lanterns, Rope, Provisions and many other things are available to the Adventurer with ready money chinking in their purse! The DM should decide what is available, how much it costs and who is selling it. A short adventure can revolve around a shopping expedition for unusual kit or having special items fabricated by a master craftsmen. Some Equipment will be found on the players adventures, some is very common and some extremely rare and difficult to obtain, making it very desirable! {{BookCat|filing=deep}}
{{BookCat}}

revision.text:
== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Krjohnson!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 21:32, 22 April 2012 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Александр Цамутали!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.

page.title: Abstract Algebra/Group Theory/Normal subgroups and Quotient groups

revision.comment: /* Quotients with respect to Normal Subgroups */ only with \in this is a statement
revision.text:
{{TOC right}} In the preliminary chapter we discussed equivalence classes on sets. If the reader has not yet mastered this notion, he/she is advised to do so before starting this section.
== Normal Subgroups ==
Recall the definition of kernel in the previous section. We will exhibit an interesting feature it possesses. Namely, let <math>ak\,,\,k\in\ker\,\phi\leq G</math> be in the coset <math>a\ker\,\phi</math>. Then there exists a <math>k^\prime\in\ker\,\phi</math> such that <math>k^\prime a=ak</math> for all <math>a\in G</math>. This is easy to see because a coset of the kernel includes all elements in <math>G</math> that are mapped to a paticular element. The kernel inspires us to look for what are called ''normal subgroups''.
'''Definition 1:''' A subgroup <math>N\leq G</math> is called ''normal'' if <math>gNg^{-1}=N</math> for all <math>g\in G</math>. We may sometimes write <math>N\trianglelefteq G</math> to emphasize that <math>N</math> is normal in <math>G</math>.
'''Theorem 2:''' A subgroup <math>N\leq G</math> is normal if and only if <math>gN=Ng</math> for all <math>g\in G</math>.
''Proof'': By the definition, a subgroup is normal if and only if <math>gNg^{-1}=N</math> since conjugation is a bijection. The theorem follows by multiplying on the right by <math>g</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
We stated that the kernel is a normal subgroup in the introduction, so we had better well prove it!
'''Theorem 3:''' Let <math>\phi\,:\,G\rightarrow G^\prime</math> be any homomorphism. Then <math>\ker\phi\leq G</math> is normal.
''Proof'': Let <math>k\in\ker\,\phi</math> and <math>g\in G</math>. Then <math>\phi(gkg^{-1})=\phi(g)e^\prime\phi(g)^{-1}=e^\prime</math>, so <math>gkg^{-1}\in\ker\phi</math>, proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 4:''' Let <math>G,G^\prime</math> be groups and <math>\phi\,:\, G\rightarrow G^\prime</math> a group homomorphism. Then if <math>H</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math>, then <math>\phi^{-1}(H)</math> is normal in <math>G</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>g\in G</math> and <math>h\in \phi^{-1}(H)</math>. Then <math>\phi(ghg^{-1})=\phi(g)\phi(h)\phi(g)^{-1}\in H</math> since <math>H</math> is normal in <math>\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math>, and so <math>ghg^{-1}\in \phi^{-1}(H)</math>, proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 5:''' Let <math>G,G^\prime</math> be groups and <math>\phi\,:\, G\rightarrow G^\prime</math> a group homomorphism. Then if <math>H</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>, <math>\phi(H)</math> is normal in <math>\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>g^\prime \in \mathrm{im}\,\phi</math> And <math>h\in H</math>. Then if <math>g\in G</math> such that <math>\phi(g)=g^\prime</math>, we have <math>g^\prime \phi(h) {g^\prime}^{-1}=\phi(g)\phi(h)\phi(g)^{-1}=\phi(ghg^{-1})=\phi(h^\prime)\in\phi(H)</math> for some <math>h^\prime\in H</math> since <math>H</math> is normal. Thus <math>g^\prime \phi(H){g^\prime}^{-1}=\phi(H)</math> for all <math>g^\prime\in\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math> and so <math>H</math> is normal in <math>\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Corollary 6:''' Let <math>G,G^\prime</math> be groups and <math>\phi\,:\, G\rightarrow G^\prime</math> a surjective group homomorphism. Then if <math>H</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>, <math>\phi(H)</math> is normal in <math>G^\prime</math>.
''Proof'': Replace <math>\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math> with <math>G^\prime</math> in the proof of Theorem 5. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Remark 7:''' If <math>H</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math> and <math>K</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>H</math>, it does '''not''' necessarily imply that <math>K</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>. The reader is invited to display a counterexample of this.
'''Theorem 8:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>H,K</math> be subgroups. Then
:i) If <math>H</math> is normal, then <math>HK=KH</math> is a subgroup of <math>G</math>.
:ii) If both <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are normal, then <math>HK=KH</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>.
:iii) If <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are normal, then <math>H\cap K</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>.
''Proof'': i) Let <math>H</math> be normal. First, since for each <math>k\in K</math>, there exists <math>h,h^\prime\in H</math> such that <math>kh=h^\prime k</math>, so <math>KH=HK</math>. To show <math>HK</math> is a subgroup, let <math>hk,h^\prime k^\prime\in HK</math>. Then <math>h^\prime k^\prime (hk)^{-1}=h^\prime k^\prime k^{-1} h^{-1}=h^\prime h^{\prime\prime}k^\prime k^{-1}\in HK</math> for some <math>h^{\prime\prime}\in H</math> since <math>H</math> is normal, and so <math>HK</math> is a subgroup.
ii) Let <math>g\in G</math> and <math>hk\in HK</math>. Then since both <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are normal, there exists <math>h^\prime\in H\, ,\,k^\prime\in K</math> such that <math>ghkg^{-1}=ghg^{-1}k^\prime=gg^{-1}h^\prime k^\prime =h^\prime k^\prime\in HK</math>. It follows that <math>gHKg^{-1}=HK</math> and so <math>HK</math> is normal.
iii) Let <math>g\in G</math> and <math>h\in H\cap K</math>. Then <math>ghg^{-1}\in H</math> since H is normal, and similarly <math>ghg^{-1}\in K</math>. Thus <math>ghg^{-1}\in H\cap K</math> and it follows that <math>H\cap K</math> is normal. {{Unicode|∎}}
=== Examples of Normal Subgroups ===
In the following, let <math>G</math> be any group. Then <math>G</math> has associated with it the following normal subgroups.
:i) The ''center'' of <math>G</math>, denoted <math>Z(G)</math>, is the subgroup of elements which commute with all others. <math>Z(G)=\{z\in G\mid (\forall g\in G) zg=gz\}</math>. That <math>Z(G)</math> is a normal subgroup is easy to verify and is left to the reader.
:ii) The ''commutator subgroup'' of <math>G</math>, denoted <math>G^{(1)}</math> or <math>[G,G]</math>, is the subgroup generated by the subset <math>\{[g,h]\mid g,h\in G\}</math> where <math>[g,h]=g^{-1}h^{-1}gh</math> for all <math>g,h\in G</math>. For <math>s\in G</math>, we introduce the shorthand <math>sgs^{-1}=g^s</math>. Then we have <math>s[g,h]s^{-1}=[g^s,h^s]</math>, such that for any product of commutators <math>[g_1,h_1][g_2,h_2]...[g_n,h_n]</math> where all elements are in <math>G</math>, we have <math>s[g_1,h_1][g_2,h_2]...[g_n,h_n]s^{-1}=[g_1^s,h_1^s][g_2^s,h_2^s]...[g_n^s,h_n^s]</math>, and so <math>G^{(1)}</math> is normal.
'''Remark 9:''' We can iterate the commutator subgroup construction and define <math>G^{(0)}=G</math> and <math>G^{(n)}=[G^{(n-1)},G^{(n-1)}]</math> for all <math>n\in \mathbb{N}</math>. We will not use the commutator subgroup in future results in this book, so for us it is merely a curiosity.
== Equivalence Relations on Groups ==
Why are normal subgroups important? In the preliminary chapter we discussed equialence relations and the associated set of equivalence classes. If <math>G</math> is a group and <math>\sim</math> is an equivalence relation, when does <math>G/\sim</math> admit a group structure? Of course we have to specify the multiplication on <math>G/\sim</math>. We will do so now.
'''Definition 10:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>\sim</math> is an equivalence relation on <math>G</math>, we define multiplication on the equivalence classes in <math>G/\sim</math> such that for all <math>a,b\in G</math>,
:<math>[a][b]=[ab]</math>
This is indeed the only natural way to do it. Take the two equivalence classes, choose representatives, compute their product and take its equivalence class. The alert reader will have only one thing on his/her mind: is this well defined? For a general equivalence relation, the answer is no. The reader is invited to come up with an example. What is more interesting is ''when'' is it well defined? By the definition above, we obviously need the projection map <math>\pi\,:\, G\rightarrow G/\sim</math> defined by <math>a\mapsto [a]</math> to be a homomorphism. We can in fact condense the requirements down to two, both having to do with cancellation laws.
'''Theorem 11:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>\sim</math> an equivalence relation on <math>G</math>. Then <math>G/\sim</math> is a group under the natural multiplication if and only if for all <math>a,b,g\in G</math>
:<math>a\sim b\,\Leftrightarrow ag\sim bg \wedge ga\sim gb</math>.
''Proof'': Assume <math>G/\sim</math> is a group. Since <math>a\sim b \,\Leftrightarrow [a]=[b]</math>, the property follows from the cancellation laws in <math>G</math>. Assume now that the property holds. Then its multiplication rule is well defined, and must verify that <math>G/\sim</math> is a group. Let <math>a,b,c\in G</math>, then associativity is inherited from <math>G</math>:
:<math>([a][b])[c]=[ab][c]=[(ab)c]=[a(bc)]=[a][bc]=[a]([b][c])</math>.
The identity in <math>G/\sim</math> is the equivalence class of <math>e\in G</math>, <math>[e]</math>:
:<math>[e][a]=[ea]=[a]=[ae]=[a][e]</math>.
Finally, the inverse of <math>[a]</math> is <math>[a^{-1}]</math>:
:<math>[g][g^{-1}]=[gg^{-1}]=[e]=[g^{-1}g]=[g^{-1}][g]</math>.
So <math>G/\sim</math> really defines a group structure, proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
We will call an equivalence relation <math>\sim</math> ''compatible'' with <math>G</math> if <math>G/\sim</math> is a group. Then, <math>G/\sim</math> is called the ''quotient group'' of <math>G</math> by <math>\sim</math>. Also, as an immediate consequence, this makes <math>\pi\,:\, G\rightarrow G/\sim</math> into a homomorphism, but not just any homomorphism! It satisfies a universal property!
[[File:Diagramquotient.png|thumb|Commutative diagram showing the universal property satisfied by the projection homomorphism.]] '''Theorem 12:''' Let <math>\sim</math> be en equivalence relation compatible with <math>G</math>, and <math>\phi\,:\, G\rightarrow H</math> a group homomorphism such that <math>a\sim b \,\Rightarrow\, \phi(a)=\phi(b)</math>. Then there exists a unique homomorphism <math>\tilde{\phi}\,:\, G/\sim\rightarrow H</math> such that <math>\phi=\tilde{\phi}\circ\pi</math>.
''Proof'': In the preliminary chapter on set theory, we showed the corresponding statement for sets, so we know that <math>\tilde{\phi}</math> exists as a function between sets. We have to show that it is a homomorphism. This follows immediately: since <math>\tilde{\phi}([a])=\phi(a)</math> by commutativity, we have <math>\tilde{\phi}([a])\tilde{\phi}([b])=\phi(a)\phi(b)=\phi(ab)=\tilde{\phi}([ab])=\tilde{\phi}([a][b])</math>. As stated already, <math>\tilde{\phi}([a])=\phi(a)</math> shows uniqueness, proving the theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Lemma 13:''' Let <math>\sim</math> be an equivalence relation on a group <math>G</math> such that <math>a\sim b \,\Leftrightarrow ga=gb</math>. Then <math>H=[e]</math> is a subgroup of <math>G</math> and <math>a\sim b \,\Leftrightarrow\, a^{-1}b\in H\,\Leftrightarrow \, aH=bH</math>.
''Proof'': First off, <math>H</math> is nonempty since <math>e\in H</math>. Let <math>a,b\in H</math>. Then <math>b\sim e \,\Leftrightarrow\, e\sim b^{-1}</math> by multiplying on the left by <math>b^{-1}</math>. Then since <math>e\sim a</math> we have <math>a^{-1}\sim e</math> by the same argument. Applying transitivity gives <math>a^{-1}\sim b^{-1}</math>. Finally, multiplying on the left by <math>a</math> gives <math>e\sim ab^{-1}</math>, giving <math>ab^{-1}\in H</math> and so <math>H=[e]</math> is a subgroup.
Assume <math>a\sim b</math> for <math>a,b\in G</math>. Then <math>[a]=[b]</math> implying <math>[a^{-1}b]=[e]</math>. Thus <math>a^{-1}b\in [e]</math>. Now assume <math>a^{-1}b\in [e]</math>. Then <math>[a^{-1}b]=[e]</math> and so <math>[a]=[b]</math> and finally <math>a\sim b</math>.
Assume <math>a^{-1}b\in H</math>. Then since <math>H</math> is a subgroup, we have <math>a^{-1}bH=H</math> and so <math>aH=bH</math>. Finally, assume <math>aH=bH</math>. Then <math>a^{-1}bH=H</math>. Since in paticular <math>e\in H</math>, this implies <math>a^{-1}b\in H</math>, completing the proof. {{Unicode|∎}}
The mirror version using right cosets and the equivalence relation <math>a\sim b \,\Leftrightarrow ag=bg</math> and <math>a\sim b \,\Leftrightarrow\, ab^{-1}\in H\,\Leftrightarrow \, Ha=Hb</math> is completely analogous. Stating the theorem and writing out the proof is left to the reader as an exercise.
We have showed how an equialence relation defines a subgroup of <math>G</math>. In fact the equivalence classes are all cosets of this subgroup. We will now go the other way, and show how a subgroup defines an equivalence relation on <math>G</math>.
'''Lemma 14:''' Let <math>H</math> be a subgroup of a group <math>G</math>. Then,
:i) <math>a\sim_L b\,\Leftrightarrow\,a^{-1}b\in H\,\Leftrightarrow\,aH=bH</math> is an equivalence relation such that <math>a\sim_L b\,\Leftrightarrow\,ga\sim_L gb</math> for all <math>g\in G</math>.
:ii) <math>a\sim_R b\,\Leftrightarrow\,ab^{-1}\in H\,\Leftrightarrow\,Ha=Hb</math> is an equivalence relation such that <math>a\sim_R b\,\Leftrightarrow\,ag\sim_R bg</math> for all <math>g\in G</math>.
''Proof'': We will prove i). The proof for ii) is similar and is left as an exercise for the reader.
The fact that <math>\sim</math> is an equivalence relation and that <math>a^{-1}b\in H\,\Leftrightarrow\,aH=bH</math> was proven in the section on subgroups. Assume <math>a\sim_L b</math>. Then for all <math>g\in G</math>, <math>(ga)^{-1}(gb)=a^{-1}g^{-1}gb=a^{-1}b\in H</math> such that <math>ga\sim_L gb</math>. Now assume <math>ga\sim_L gb</math>, Then <math>a^{-1}b=a^{-1}g^{-1}gb=(ga)^{-1}(gb)\in H</math> such that <math>a\sim_L b</math>, completing the proof. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 15:''' For every equivalence relation <math>\sim_L</math> on G such that <math>a\sim_L b\,\Leftrightarrow ga\sim_L gb</math>, there exists a unique subgroup <math>H</math> of <math>G</math> such that <math>G/\sim</math> are precisely the left cosets of <math>H</math>.
''Proof'': This follows from Lemma 13 and Lemma 14.
Again, the mirror statement is completely analogous. Stating the theorem is left to the reader as an exercise.
== Quotients with respect to Normal Subgroups ==
'''Lemma 16:''' An equivalence relation <math>\sim</math> on <math>G</math> is compatible with <math>G</math> if and only if <math>[e]=H</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>.
''Proof'': Assume <math>\sim</math> is compatible, <math>g\in G</math> and <math>a\in H</math>. Then <math>a\sim e</math>, and compatibility gives us <math>gag^{-1}\sim gg^{-1}=e</math>, and so <math>gag^{-1}\in H</math>. Since <math>a</math> is arbitrary, we obtain <math>gHg^{-1}=H</math> for all <math>g\in G</math> and so <math>H</math> is normal. Assume now that <math>H</math> is normal. Then <math>aH=bH\,\Leftrightarrow a^{-1}b\in H</math>, <math>Ha=Hb\,\Leftrightarrow ab^{-1} \in H</math> and <math>aH=Ha</math> for all <math>a,b\in G</math>. Using this, we obtain <math>a\sim b\,\Leftrightarrow ab^{-1}=ab^{-1}bg(bg)^{-1}\sim e \,\Leftrightarrow ab^{-1}bg=ag\sim bg</math> and similarily for the right hand case, so <math>\sim</math> is compatible with <math>G</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Definition 17:''' When an equivalence relation is given by specifying a normal subgroup <math>H</math>, the quotient group with respect to this equivalence relation is denoted <math>G/H</math>. We then refer to <math>G/H</math> as the quotient of <math>G</math> with respect to <math>H</math>, or <math>G</math> modulo <math>H</math>. Note that this complies with previous definitions of this notation.
Multiplication in <math>G/H</math> is given as before as <math>(aH)(bH)=(ab)H</math>, with identity <math>H</math> and <math>(aH)^{-1}=a^{-1}H</math> for all <math>a,b\in G</math>.
'''Definition 18:''' Let <math>H</math> be a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>. Then we define the ''projection homomorphism'' <math>\pi\,:\, G\rightarrow G/H</math> by <math>\pi(a)=aH</math> for all <math>a\in G</math>.
'''Theorem 19:''' A subgroup is normal if and only if it is the kernel of some homomorphism.
''Proof'': We have already covered the left implication. For the right implication, assume <math>H</math> is normal. Then <math>G/H</math> is a group and we have the projection homomorphism <math>\pi\,:\,G\rightarrow G/H</math> as defined above. Since for all <math>h\in H</math> we have <math>\pi(h)=hH=H</math>, <math>\ker\,\pi=H</math> and so <math>H</math> is the kernel of a homomorphism. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 20:''' Let <math>G,G^\prime</math> be groups, <math>\phi\,:\, G\rightarrow G^\prime</math> a homomorphism and <math>H</math> a normal subgroup of <math>G</math> such that <math>H\subseteq \ker\,\phi</math>. Then there exists a unique homomorphism <math>\tilde{\phi}\,:\,G/H\rightarrow G^\prime</math> such that <math>\tilde{\phi}\circ\pi=\phi</math>.
''Proof'': This follows from Theorem 12 by letting <math>a\sim b\,\Leftrightarrow aH=bH</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
== The Isomorphism Theorems ==
[[File:FirstIsoThm.png|thumb|Commutative diagram showing the first isomorphism theorem. <math>\tilde{\phi}</math> is an isomorphism.]] '''Theorem 21 (First Isomorphism Theorem):''' Let <math>G,G^\prime</math> be groups and <math>\phi\,:\, G\rightarrow G^\prime</math> a homomorphism. Then <math>G/\ker\,\phi \approx \mathrm{im}\, \phi</math>.
''Proof'': From Theorem 20 we have that there exists a unique homomorphism <math>\tilde{\phi}\,:\, G/\ker\,\phi \rightarrow G^\prime</math> such that <math>\phi=\tilde{\phi}\circ\pi</math>. We have to show that <math>\tilde{\phi}</math> is an isomorphism when we corestrict to <math>\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math>. This is immediate, since <math>\phi(a)=\phi(b)\,\Leftrightarrow a\ker\phi=b\ker\phi</math> by Lemma 13, so that <math>\tilde{\phi}</math> is injective, and for any <math>g^\prime\in\mathrm{im}\,\phi</math> there is a <math>g\in G</math> such that <math>\phi(g)=\tilde{\phi}(g\ker\,\phi)=g^\prime</math> so that it is surjective and therefore an isomorphism. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Lemma 22:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group, <math>H</math> a subgroup and <math>K</math> a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>. Then <math>H\cap K</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>H</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>h\in H</math> and <math>k\in H\cap K</math>. Then <math>hkh^{-1}\in H</math> since <math>h,k\in H</math> and <math>H</math> is a subgroup and <math>hkh^{-1}\in K</math> since <math>k\in K</math>, <math>h\in G</math> and <math>K</math> is normal in <math>G</math>. Thus <math>hkh^{-1}\in H\cap K</math> and <math>H\cap K</math> is normal in <math>H</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 23 (Second Isomorphism Theorem):''' Let <math>G</math> be a group, <math>H</math> a subgroup and <math>K</math> a normal subgroup of <math>G</math>. Then <math>HK/K\approx \frac{H}{H\cap K}</math>.
''Proof'': Define <math>\phi\,:\, H\rightarrow HK/K</math> by <math>\phi(h)=hK</math> for all <math>h\in H</math>. <math>\phi</math> is surjective since any element in <math>HK</math> can be written as <math>hk</math> with <math>h\in H</math> and <math>k\in K</math>, so <math>\phi(h)=\pi(hk)=hkK=hK</math>. We also have that <math>\ker\,\phi=\{h\in H\mid hK=K\}=\{h\in H\mid h\in K\}=H\cap K</math> and so <math>HK/K\approx \frac{H}{H\cap K}</math> by the first isomorphism theorem. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Lemma 24:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group, and let <math>H,K</math> be normal subgroups of <math>G</math> such that <math>K\subseteq H\subseteq G</math>. Then <math>H/K</math> is a normal subgroup of <math>G/K</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>h\in H</math> and <math>g\in G</math>. Then <math>ghg^{-1}=h^\prime</math> for some <math>h^\prime\in H</math> since <math>H</math> is normal. Thus <math>(gK)(hK)(gK)^{-1}=(ghg^{-1})K=h^\prime K</math>, showing that <math>H/K</math> is normal in <math>G/K</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 25 (Third Isomorphism Theorem)''' Let <math>G</math> be a group, and let <math>H,K</math> be normal subgroups of <math>G</math> such that <math>K\subseteq H\subseteq G</math>. Then <math>\frac{G/K}{H/K}\approx G/H</math>.
''Proof'': Let <math>\phi\,:\, G/K\rightarrow G/H</math> be given by <math>\phi(gK)=gH</math>. This is well defined and surjective since <math>K\subseteq H</math>, and is a homomorphism. Its kernel is given by <math>\ker\,\phi=\{gK\in G/K\mid gH=H\}=\{gK\in G/K\mid g\in H\}=H/K</math>, so by the first isomorphism theorem, <math>\frac{G/K}{H/K}\approx G/H</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Theorem 26 (The Correspondence Theorem):''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>K</math> be a normal subgroup. Now let <math>A=\{H\leq G\mid K\leq H\}</math> and <math>B=\{H^\prime\mid H^\prime \leq G/K\}</math>. Then <math>\pi\,:\, H\mapsto \pi(H)</math> is an order-preserving bijection from <math>A</math> to <math>B</math>.
''Proof'': We must show injectivity and surjectivity. For injectivity, note that if <math>K\leq H</math>, then <math>\pi^{-1}(\pi(H))=HK=H</math>, so if <math>H_1,H_2\in A</math> such that <math>\pi(H_1)=\pi(H_2)</math>, then <math>H_1=\pi^{-1}(\pi(H_1))=\pi^{-1}(\pi(H_2))=H_2</math>, proving injectivity. For surjectivity, let <math>H^\prime\in B</math>. Then <math>K\leq \pi^{-1}(H^\prime)\leq G</math>, so that <math>\pi^{-1}(H^\prime)\in A</math>, and <math>\pi(\pi^{-1}(H^\prime))=H^\prime</math>, proving surjectivity. Lastly, since <math>H_1\subseteq H_2</math> implies that <math>\pi(H_1)\subseteq\pi(H_2)</math>, the bijection is order-preserving. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Note 27:''' The correspondence Theorem is sometimes called ''The Forth Isomorphism Theorem''.
'''Theorem 28:''' Let <math>H\in A</math> from Theorem 26. Then <math>H</math> is normal if and only if <math>\pi(H)</math> is normal in <math>G/K</math>, and then <math>G/H\approx \frac{G/K}{\pi(H)}</math>.
''Proof'': Since <math>\pi</math> is surjective, <math>H</math> normal implies <math>\pi(H)</math> normal. Assume that <math>\pi(H)</math> is normal. Then <math>\pi^{-1}(\pi(H))=H</math> and so <math>H</math> is normal since it is the preimage of a normal subgroup. To show the isomorphism, let <math>\phi\,:\,G\rightarrow \frac{G/K}{\pi(H)}</math> be given by a composition of projections: <math>\phi\,:\,\pi_{\pi(H)}\circ\pi_K</math>. Then <math>\ker\,\phi=\{g\in G\mid \phi(g)=\pi(H)\}=\{g\in G\mid \pi(g)\in \pi(H)\}=\pi^{-1}(\pi(H))=H</math>, so by the first isomorphism teorem, <math>G/H\approx\frac{G/K}{\pi(H)}</math>. {{Unicode|∎}}
'''Corollary 29:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>H</math> a normal subgroup. Then for any <math>K^\prime\leq G/H</math> there exists a unique subgroup <math>K\leq G</math> such that <math>H\leq K\leq G</math> and <math>K=K^\prime H</math>. Also, <math>K</math> is normal in <math>G</math> if and only if <math>K^\prime</math> is normal in <math>G/H</math>.
''Proof'': From Theorem 26 we have that the projection <math>K\mapsto \pi(K)=K^\prime</math> is a bijection, and since <math>\pi(g)=gH</math> for all <math>g\in G</math>, we have <math>K=K^\prime H</math>. The second part follows from Theorem 28. {{Unicode|∎}}
== Simple Groups ==
'''Definition 30:''' A group is called ''simple'' is it has no non-trivial proper normal subgroups.
'''Example 31:''' Every cyclic group <math>\mathbb{Z}_p</math>, where <math>p</math> is prime, is simple.
'''Definition 32:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>H</math> a normal subgroup. <math>H</math> is called a ''maximal normal subgroup'' if for any normal subgroup <math>K</math> of <math>G</math>, we have <math>K\subseteq H</math>.
'''Theorem 33:''' Let <math>G</math> be a group and <math>H</math> a normal subgroup. Then <math>H</math> is a maximal normal subgroup if and only if the quotient <math>G/H</math> is simple.
''Proof'': By Theorem 26 and Theorem 28, <math>G/H</math> has a nontrivial normal subgroup if and only if there exists a proper normal subgroup <math>K</math> of <math>G</math> such that <math>H\leq K\leq G</math>. That is, <math>H</math> is not maximal if ans only if <math>G/H</math> is not simple. The theorem follows. {{Unicode|∎}}
== Problems ==
'''Problem 1:''' Recall the unitary and special unitary groups from the section about subgroups. Define the ''projective unitary group of order ''<math>n</math> as the group <math>PU(n)=U(n)/Z(U(n))</math>. Similarily, define the ''projective special unitary group of order ''<math>n</math> as <math>PSU(n)=SU(n)/Z(SU(n))</math>.
:i) Show that <math>Z(SU(n))=SU(n)\cap Z(U(n)\approx \mathbb{Z}_n</math>
:ii) Using the second isomorphism theorem, show that <math>PSU(n)\approx PU(n)</math>.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: How To Succeed in College/Fraternities and Sororities

revision.text:
==Networking== A very effective way to obtain a job after college is to utilize networking - i.e., people you know. Some research indicates that students who utilize their fraternity and sorority networks, including other members and alumni, are more likely to obtain high paying jobs than individuals who do not have these resources.<ref name="Marmaros2002">Marmaros, D., & Sacerdote, B. (2002). Peer and social networks in job search. European Economic Review, 46(4–5), 870–879. doi:10.1016/S0014-2921(01)00221-5</ref> Former college students, when asked, reported that networking through their fraternity or sorority was a very helpful way to find a good job. Students receiving help and advice from their fraternity or sorority members are more likely to not only find a job, but to find a job they like.<ref name="Pike2003">Pike, G. R. (2003). Membership in a Fraternity or Sorority, Student Engagement, and Educational Outcomes at AAU Public Research Universities. Journal of College Student Development, 44(3), 369–382. doi:10.1353/csd.2003.0031</ref> Finding a job through fraternity and sorority networks often results in a greater mean salary than those who find jobs through other networks or through other references, like: professors, alumni, career services, relatives, or alone.
Fraternity and sorority members are also often more involved than students not in fraternities or sororities in activities relating to student learning and intellectual development. Some fraternities and sororities also have a GPA requirement that must be maintained, which leads to greater student success in college. Furthermore, students in fraternities and sororities reported having significantly higher levels of active and collaborative learning, as well as greater interaction with their professors, other faculty members, and peers. This resulted in advantages in both academic and personal development.<ref name="Pike2003"/>
== Fraternity and Sorority Membership and Drinking Alcohol == Seven out of eight college students (or 87.5%) drink and 44% engage in binge drinking.<ref name="Sher2001">Sher, K J, B D Bartholow, and S Nanda. 2001. “Short- and long-term effects of fraternity and sorority membership on heavy drinking: a social norms perspective.” Psychology of Addictive Behaviors: Journal of the Society of Psychologists in Addictive Behaviors 15(1):42-51.</ref> College is a period of time associated with heavy levels of drinking. It is also associated with elevated risk for acute health problems, including serious injury and psychological distress. Membership in a [[w:fraternity|fraternity]] or [[w:sorority|sorority]] leads to drinking more heavily and frequently.<ref name="Sher2001"/><ref name="Park2008">Park, Aesoon, Kenneth J. Sher, and Jennifer L. Krull. 2008. “Risky Drinking in College Changes as Fraternity/Sorority Affiliation Changes: A Person–Environment Perspective.” Psychology of addictive behaviors : journal of the Society of Psychologists in Addictive Behaviors 22(2):219-229.</ref> Additionally, membership in a fraternity or sorority increases the odds of developing dependence symptoms, initiating or continuing abusive alcohol use patterns, and experiencing alcohol related problems.<ref name="Sher2001"/> Those who join fraternities later in their college careers experience an increase in abusive alcohol consumption while those who leave fraternities and sororities experience a decrease in such activities.<ref name="Park2008"/>
The reasons why members of fraternities and sororities are more likely to consume alcohol are not perfectly clear, but it appears as though social norms play a prominent role.<ref name="Sher2001"/> Members of these groups view drinking as more of a social norm. However, many members of these groups enter college with these beliefs, which may indicate that it is not exclusively the environments of the fraternities and sororities that lead to these attitudes and behaviors but prior views of the members.<ref name="Sher2001"/> Heavy drinkers and partiers in high school may intentionally seek out fraternity and sorority membership because they are aware of the reputation these organizations have for drinking and partying.<ref name="Park2008"/> Other factors that may contribute to alcohol use among members of these groups could be the characteristics of the members. Members of these groups tend to score high on extraversion and also tend to be impulsive.<ref name="Sher2001"/><ref name="Park2008"/>
Despite the differences in drinking during college, three years after college the levels of drinking of members of fraternities and sororities does not appear to be significantly different from that of college graduates who were not in these types of organizations. This is suggestive of a pro-drinking environment in fraternities and sororities.<ref name="Sher2001"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: /* How to Find a Great Wedding Photographer */ new section
revision.text:
== How to Find a Great Wedding Photographer ==
A wedding is one of life’s most important ceremonies that celebrate the union of two people in marriage, with friends and family coming together to attend the special event. What better way to save those happy and touching memories during the celebration than capturing them with a digital camera. What makes those memories even more unforgettable is when the pictures are taken by a professional photographer. For this reason, it is no wonder couples are seeking expert photography Melbourne services to help them make their wedding day extraordinary.
True, there are lots of [http://www.liveloveshare.com.au wedding photography Melbourne] service providers to choose from today, but what needs to be given consideration at this point is finding the right one that can work well with you, and can produce quality photographs. With that said, you need to come up with a certain criteria for selecting the best one. It is only right that you hire the most excellent wedding photographer, as the ceremony happens only once and that means everything has to be perfect in every way.
When you have set the date of your wedding day, it is time to start preparing. One that has to be given importance, apart from the flower arrangements, the event attendees, and the like, is getting an expert photography Melbourne service provider who is able to encapsulate each little cherished moment happening at the wedding, through the photographer’s camera.
What makes an expert wedding photographer is his/her years of experience and eye for creativity. If a photographer has been in the business for quite some time, it is high likely that he/she already possesses the skill and talent to snap perfect images of his/her clients. He/She does settle for shots that have been done before; he/she rather takes it to a whole new level, making it more eye-catching and memorable. Apart from being creative, he/she must understand the customers and their requests, and deliver to the best of his/her potential, to produce a set of brilliant and stunning photos people would surely talk about for years.
Experienced wedding photography Melbourne service providers can present a beautiful collection of pictures in his/her portfolio. Moreover, their clientele must have an outstanding review of their services. This would then indicate that he/she is not only a professional, but also an exceptional worker who will do whatever it takes to carry out his/her job.
Take these pointers into account and you just might be able to get just the right photography Melbourne service provider for your wedding. It may take time to find the ideal expert to do the job, but it will all be worth it when you see the photographs he/she has taken.

=== Usage ===
This template is a trivial wrapper around [[Help:Editing#Interlanguage links|interlanguage links]]. It is meant as a way to prevent interlanguage links from appearing in print versions of books such as PDF files generated by [[:de:Benutzer:Dirk_Huenniger/wb2pdf|wb2pdf]]. There are two unnamed arguments: the first is the language code; the second, the name of the destination page in the sister wiki. Therefore, <nowiki>{{Haskell/Interlanguage|nl|Analyse}}</nowiki> becomes: <nowiki>[[nl:Analyse]]</nowiki> <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS -->
[[Category:Exclude in print]] [[Category:Haskell/Templates|Interlanguage]] </includeonly>

*[[:File:Schloss Lichtenstein 04-2010.jpg]] is a good photo of Lichtenstein ==Languages of India== [[w:Languages of India]], [[w:Names of the Republic of India in its official languages]], [[w:Languages with official status in India]], [[d:Q668]] ===Major languages=== * English - India - en - official * Hindi - भारत - hi - official * Bengali - ভারত - bn - official regional - 83m * Telugu - భారత దేశము - te - official regional - 74m * Marathi - भारत - mr - 72m * Tamil - இந்தியா - ta - 61m * Urdu - بھارت - ur - 52m * Gujarati - ભારત - gu - 46m * Kannada - ಭಾರತ - kn - 38m * Malayalam - ഇന്ത്യ - ml - 33m * Oriya - ଭାରତ - or - 33m * Maithili - भारत - mai (pos. bh?) - 32m * Punjabi - ਭਾਰਤ - pa - 29m ===Other languages=== * French - Inde - fr - unknown ===List of names of every language recognized in the constitution or official in any state or union territory=== ====Official==== Hindi, English ====Recognized in constitution by number of speakers==== Bengali, Telugu, Marathi, Tamil, Urdu, Gujarati, Malayalam, Oriya, Maithili, Punjabi, Assamese, Santali, Kashmiri, Nepali, Konkani, Sindhi, Dogri, Meithei/Manipuri, Bodo, Sanskrit ====Not mentioned above but official in at least one state or union territory==== (no order) French ✓, Portuguese ✓, Bhojpuri, Chhattisgarhi, Haryanvi (Hindi dialect?), Mizo, Bagri (dialect of Rhajastani), Kokborok ===Notes=== * Possibly create [[Wikijunior:Countries A-Z/India/Languages]] to display all approx. 30 official languages, but only have top four (English, Hindi, Bengali, Telugu), with the possible addition of Marathi and Tamil, on the main page? * Or alternatively a hide/show thing

page.title: Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/The Interpretation of Dreams

revision.text: {{closed|1=Deleted as out of scope [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 13:30, 23 April 2012 (UTC)}} The 1913 edition of this book is already on Wikisource [http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Interpretation_of_Dreams here], so it is against the [[WB:SOURCE|policy]] on published texts unless the author(s) are going to annotate it - which has not been stated as an objective. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 23:35, 27 February 2012 (UTC) *[[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px|alt=|link=]] '''Delete- out of scope''' [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 09:12, 28 February 2012 (UTC) *[[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px|alt=|link=]] '''Delete''': Out of scope. We can replace the root page with an interwiki redirect to the Wikisource book if desired. – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|discuss]] 15:57, 28 February 2012 (UTC) * '''Question''' Could some of the material be useful for merging into [[Lucid Dreaming]]? --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 00:16, 17 March 2012 (UTC) ::Indeed some of the content could be used for that work and probably other psychiatry books but not as a simple merge. Someone would have to carefully select the usable content and take in consideration that some of the ideas expressed on the work are now outdated. Since the work is now Wikisource I see no value in keeping this apparent duplication. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 02:29, 17 March 2012 (UTC) *[[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px|alt=|link=]]'''Delete''' Agree totally with Panic2k4 --[[User:Msaikens|Msaikens]] ([[User talk:Msaikens|discuss]] - [[Special contributions/Msaikens|contribs]]) 13: 47, 17 March 2012 (EST) {{end closed}}

{{Documentation subpage}} === Usage === 
{{Template:Wikijunior:Countries A-Z/Image||size={{{size|300}}|date-of-removal=}}
=== See also ===

==Zyprexa== [[File:Zyprexa.jpg|thumb|Zyprexa (olanzapine) 10 mg tablets]] [[w: Olanzapine | Zyprexa]] (olanzapine), a product of the pharmaceutical giant [[w: Eli_Lilly_and_Company | Eli Lilly & Co]], was introduced in 1996 as an atypical [[w: Antipsychotic | antipsychotic]] <ref name="Berenson">Berenson, Alex (2007). Lily Settles with 18,000 over Zyprexa. The New York Times http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9f00e5db1430f936a35752c0a9619c8b63 </ref>. Approved by the [[w: Food_and_Drug_Administration | FDA]] for the treatment of Schizophrenia and Bipolar Mania, Zyprexa accounted for almost one-third of annual revenue for Eli Lilly since the drug's introduction, with global sales exceeding $4 billion dollars in 2006 <ref name="Berenson"/>. Zyprexa has been prescribed to nearly 26 million people since 1996 <ref> Lilly Resolves Investigations of Past Zyprexa Marketing and Promotional Practices (2009). Eli Lilly and Company. http://newsroom.lilly.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=359242 </ref>.
===Marketing Strategy=== Eli Lilly is widely criticized for employing irresponsible marketing strategies that down-played the risks and promoted "off-label" usage of Zyprexa.
====''<small>Off-label Marketing</small>''==== :While only approved for schizophrenia and bipolar mania, the drug was marketed to doctors and patients for a wide range of unapproved and questionable treatments. For example, Eli Lilly established a "Viva Zyprexa" campaign that promoted the use of Zyprexa for symptoms including agitation, hostility, aggression, depression, and sleep or mood disturbances <ref name="Settlement"> Eli Lilly Zyprexa Settlement: Drug Maker to Pay Record $1.42 Billion (2009). Find Law. http://commonlaw.findlaw.com/2009/01/eli-lilly-zyprexa-settlement-drug-maker-to-pay-record-142-billion.html </ref>. No specific clinical studies had been performed to examine Zyprexa's effect on these symptoms.
:Eli Lilly also specifically targeted the elderly suffering from dementia and Alzheimer's <ref name="generics"> Eli Lilly profit drops sharply on Zyprexa generics (2012). Reuters. http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/31/us-elililly-idUSTRE80U0R020120131 </ref>. Leaked documents show that Eli Lilly instructed pharmaceutical salespeople to make dementia the first message for primary care physicians, since Schizophrenic patients were typically reported to specialists <ref name="Berenson"/>. Similarly, other documents show Eli Lilly claiming that Zyprexa is a safe choice for treating agitation and confusion. The sales slogan "5 at 5" was allegedly used by salespeople to promote 5mg of Zyprexa at 5pm to help the elderly sleep. However, Zyprexa had not been approved for any such treatments and, in fact, suggested harmful side effects during clinical trials <ref name="Settlement"/>.
====''<small>Down-played Risks</small>''==== :Concerned that sales of the drug might suffer if they were more forthright, Eli Lilly instructed sales representatives to down-play the risks of Zyprexa. Clinical trial documents showed that 16% of patients gained more than 66 pounds within a year of use. Moreover, the effects of the drug on diabetes risk were extreme <ref name="Settlement"/>. In 2001, the American Medical Association published a study reporting that patients taking Zyprexa had a ten times higher risk of developing diabetes. Similar cases have been identified for Ketoacidosis and Pancreatitis <ref> Zyprexa: hyperglycemia and diabetes (2011). 1 Boring Old Man. http://1boringoldman.com/index.php/2011/03/26/zyprexa-hyperglycemia-and-diabetes/ </ref><ref> Zyprexa side effects (2005). Van Der Ginst Law, P.C. http://www.zyprexa-lawsuit.net/zyprexa-side-effects.shtml</ref>. Researchers also discovered that the elderly were twice as likely to suffer stroke or fatal injury while on Zyprexa. Although the FDA and regulatory agencies in the UK and Japan all warned that Zyprexa might lead to diabetes, Eli Lilly failed to disclose this information <ref name="generics"/>.
===Legal Consequences=== Through 2008, Eli Lilly had paid out over $1 billion to settle more than 32,000 Zyprexa lawsuits. In 2009, Eli Lilly entered a guilty plea with federal prosecutors of the Pennsylyvania Federal court for illegally marketing Zyprexa <ref name="Settlement"/>. While doctors hold the authority to prescribe drugs for conditions that they haven't been approved for, it is strictly illegal for pharmaceutical companies to promote off-label usage of their drugs. Eli Lilly, guilty of these actions, was forced to pay $1.42 billion for its misdemeanor violation of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act in addition to other state level lawsuits <ref name="Settlement"/>.
The terms of the plea agreement also include compulsory compliance in a corporate integrity agreement with the Office of the Inspector General (a division of the U.S. department of Health and Human Services) <ref name="generics"/>. This includes an external compliance program that will be in effect for five years, Although very similar in protocol to the internal compliance policies existing at Eli Lilly, this program includes third-party review for all systems, processes, policies, procedures, and practices.
==General Pharmaceutical Misconduct==
Such actions are widespread in the pharmaceutical industry. Of the top 10 pharmaceutical manufacturers in the world, all 10 have been involved in similar deceitful behaviors. Pfizer, the largest pharmaceutical manufacturer in the world, has been found guilty of falsely advertising and deceiving doctors about its prized possession, Lipitor. Lipitor is the best-selling prescription substance in the world <ref> Edwards, Jim (2010). Lawsuit Claims Pfizer Deceived Doctors Into Prescribing Its Cholesterol Drug Lipitor. CBS. http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505123_162-42844207/lawsuit-claims-pfizer-deceived-doctors-into-prescribing-its-cholesterol-drug-lipitor/ </ref>. Novartis, the second largest pharmaceutical manufacturer in the world, in 2010, paid over $200 million for off-label marketing <ref name="Lucy"> Lucy, C (2010). Big Pharma Lawsuits – Who Got Hit with the Biggest Settlement?. Lawyers and Settlements. http://www.lawyersandsettlements.com/blog/big-pharma-lawsuits-who-got-hit-with-the-biggest-settlement-05310.html </ref>. Sonafi, the next largest manufacturer, paid $100 million for similar activities in 2009 <ref name="Lucy"/>. Similarly, Merck, the manufacturer of Vioxx, faced billions of dollars in lawsuits for falsely advertising its blockbuster drug <ref> Wilson, Duff (2011). Merck to Pay $950 Million Over Vioxx. The New York Times. http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/23/business/merck-agrees-to-pay-950-million-in-vioxx-case.html </ref>.
===Economics of the Pharmaceutical industry=== To fully understand the ethical misconduct at hand, it is important to first examine why these major pharmaceutical companies behave in such a manner. Similar to any other business, large pharmaceutical companies are driven by profit incentives. [[w: Pharmaceutical_Research_and_Manufacturers_of_America | PhRMA]] and the [[w: IFPMA | IFPMA]], two major lobby groups for the pharmaceutical industry, state that the main objectives of the pharmaceutical industry are to deliver safe and effective pharmaceuticals to patients while also maintaining profitability for its investors <ref name="phrma"> Pharmaceutical research and manufacturers of America (2011). http://www.phrma.org/sites/default/files/159/phrma_2011_annual_report.pdf </ref> <ref name="ifpma"> International federation of pharmaceutical manufacturers & associations: corporate brochure (2010). http://www.ifpma.org/fileadmin/content/About us/1 Welcome/IFPMA_Corporate_Brochure_LowRes[1].pdf </ref> . It is this latter part of this agenda that is often responsible for pharmaceutical misconduct.
[[File:PofesionalismWikibookZyprexa1.png|right|500px| |thumb]] ====''<small>The Drug Development Process</small>''==== :In the United States alone, $300 billion dollars is spent annually on prescription drugs <ref> Huges J, Moore M, Snyder E (2002). Napsterizing Pharmaceuticals: Access, innovation, and consumer welfare. 2002 NBER Working paper </ref>. With the promise of such a large market, pharmaceutical companies actively attempt to establish a larger market presence. Over the past 20 years, nearly 1900 new pharmaceuticals have been granted approval by the FDA<ref name="phrma"/>. With a very low chance of success, the development of each one of these medicines involves significant monetary and time commitments by pharmaceutical manufacturers. Pharmaceutical companies begin with a pool of over 10,000 compounds of interest. After approximately 10 years of product testing and clinical trials, a handful are selected for in vivo evaluation. Of these handful, one or two are tested on human volunteers, with a single compound from the initial 10,000+ moving into end stage studies before being submitted for regulatory review and approval. This process requires exorbitant financial investments. Nearly $800 million is spent on average on R&D alone to bring a single new drug to market<ref name="phrma"/>. In 2009, PhRMA estimated that nearly $65.3 billion on R&D by the research-based pharmaceutical industry<ref name="phrma"/>.
====''<small>Questionable Practices</small>''==== :To recoup the R&D costs and generate profits from their discoveries, pharmaceutical manufacturers rely on patents. Currently, manufacturers of pharmaceuticals like Zyprexa have approximately 8-10 years of effective market exclusivity due to patent expirations and competition from generics <ref name="ifpma"/>. Due to this limited period of exclusivity, pharmaceutical companies have adopted many questionable strategies to maximize profits. These strategies include competitive practices with generic manufacturers, finding loopholes in the patent system, and [[w: Ghostwriter#Medical | ghostwriting]]. However, the practice that raises the greatest ethical issues is advertising to medical professionals and consumers. Over $11 billion is spent annually by pharmaceutical companies to promote and market their products <ref> Wazana A (2000). Physicians and the pharmaceutical industry. Is a gift ever just a gift? JAMA, 283, pp. 373–380 </ref>. In 2009, the top 20 proprietary pharmaceutical companies spent around 30% of their total revenues on marketing <ref> Glasgow, L J. (2001). Stretching the Limits of Intellectual Property Rights: Has the Pharmaceutical Industry Gone Too Far?, 41 IDEA 227, 250-251 </ref>. A majority of this expenditure is in the form of gifts and sponsored events for physicians. Physicians often use these company sponsored events, such as the Continuing Medical Education (CME) programs to learn about new medicines <ref> Gagnon MA., Lexchin J. (2008). The Cost of Pushing Pills: A New Estimate of Pharmaceutical Promotion Expenditures in the United States. PLoS Med 5(1):e1.doi:10.1371/journal.pmed.0050001 </ref>. As these events are sponsored and conducted by the pharmaceutical manufacturers, they provide an opportunity for these companies to falsely advertise their products. With large investments at stake and investors demanding returns, the pharmaceutical industry often exaggerates the scope and safety of their products. These false claims frequently lead to improper prescribing practices by medical practitioners and, as has been the case for Zyprexa and many other blockbuster pharmaceuticals, hundreds of thousands of injuries and deaths to patients.
==Similar Cases== Professional ethical misconduct is not limited to pharmaceutical companies. Such examples are present in every field where a professional's actions resulted in untold damages to those who depended on them. [[Professionalism/Frederic Whitehurst and the FBI | Frederic Whitehurst and the FBI]] and the [[Professionalism/Sherron Watkins and Enron | Enron scandal]] are two such examples. In the first case, Frederic Whitehurst was an FBI agent who discovered and exposed illegal evidence manipulation in the FBI crime lab. Likewise, Enron was an energy company that duped its investors out of billions of dollars by falsely reporting its finances. The consequence for the professionals in these instances is the loss of trust and, accordingly, the loss of autonomy not only for themselves but also for other professionals in their field. In the case of Eli Lilly this was demonstrated by a drop in sales of Zyprexa after the scandal broke <ref>Brickates, Val (2007). Lily CEO: Zyprexa Sales Flat. MarketWatch http://articles.marketwatch.com/2007-03-14/news/30734464_1_zyprexa-eli-lilly-lilly-ceo </ref>. Not only do these decreased sales show a lack of trust in Lilly, but also in the doctors prescribing this drug and the FDA, who approves it for general market sale. Similarly, Eli Lilly is now subject to supervision by the Office of the Inspector General as they were no longer deemed trustworthy to ethically regulate their actions. For the FBI, the loss of autonomy played out in the form of investigation and accreditation by the American Society of Crime Laboratory Directors while the consequences for Enron and Arthur Andersen were far more severe. Both companies were virtually run out of business. Moreover, their actions led to the enactment of many laws regulating auditing practices nationwide. Companies that had no part in this scandal felt the backlash.
==Diminishing Professional Trust== All of these examples are from situations that, on the surface, are vastly different from each other, yet share a common theme. In each, there existed a group of professionals, organizations like Lilly, the FBI, and Enron, trusted by the public and, subsequently, given a certain autonomy. In each situation, these professionals failed in their duties to serve the public, resulting in deaths, wrongful convictions, or loss of billions of dollars. However, these consequences extend beyond these casualties. Such actions lead to a complete loss of trust and, therefore, autonomy for these companies and the associated professionals. From these cases it is evident that autonomy is an important, perhaps even fundamental, element of being a professional. But if this power is abused it will quickly be revoked. To keep this autonomy, professionals must be trusted. Therefore, maintaining trust is an essential part of being a true professional.
==References==
<references />

page.title: How To Succeed in College/Sexual Health

revision.text:
== Sexual Health Statistics == As of 2008, 98% of women and 97% of men between the ages of 25-44 reported having had vaginal intercourse, 89% of women and 90% of men reported having had oral sex with an opposite sex partner, and 36% of women and 44% of men reported having had anal sex with an opposite sex partner. Onset of sexual activity begins after age 15, and by age 24 most people have had sex. Attending college slightly reduces the odds of having had any form of sex compared to those with no high school diploma, but not substantially.<ref name="NHSR2008">Sexual behavior, sexual attraction, and sexual identity in the United States: data from the 2006- 2008 National Survey of Family Growth.” National Health Statistics Reports (36):1-36.</ref>
Women are twice as likely as men to have had any type of sex with the same sex. For women aged 18 – 19 years old, 90% identified themselves as heterosexual, 1.9% homosexual, and 5.8% bisexual. For males of the same age, 96% said they were heterosexual, 1.6% homosexual, and 1.1% bisexual.
==Sexual Dangers == Individuals who engaged in riskier sex - sex with a non-intimate person, sex without a condom, and casual sex - in high school are likely to continue to engage in riskier sex in college, as most social behavior does not change in this transition.<ref name="Bailey2008">Bailey, Jennifer A., Charles B. Fleming, Jessica N. Henson, Richard F. Catalano, and Kevin P. Haggerty. 2008. “Sexual Risk Behavior 6 Months Post-High School: Associations with College Attendance, Living with a Parent, and Prior Risk Behavior.” Journal of Adolescent Health 42(6):573-579 Web. 13 Mar. 2012</ref> These behaviors are riskier because they increase the odds of both sexually transmitted infections and sexual violence. According to one recent survey, about 64% of college students engage in these types of risky behaviors.<ref name="Bailey2008"/>
===References:=== {{reflist}} {{BookCat}}

revision.text: The most sacred of our laws – the Constitution- contains a number of articles that guarantee the rights of minorities to lead a life of dignity and equality. However, to enable us to assess the actual impact of the comprehensive legislation for an egalitarian society conceived by our founding fathers, I wish to flag certain news items that have appeared in the national press in the last two months – cases and incidents that we have read without even raising an eyebrow because they are so commonplace.

page.title: How To Succeed in College/Safety and Security

revision.text:
At many colleges and universities across the US, safety is a prominent concern. In 1990, the Clery Act was passed to make it a requirement for schools to release all information regarding crime in the surrounding area. This act made it easy for people to see the safety of schools before committing to a university with high crime rates in the area. The act has encouraged universities to be more open about criminal activity in the surrounding area. Many universities now send emails to all students, faculty, and staff whenever a criminal act occurs in the immediate vicinity of the university. Despite the increased efforts of colleges and universities to make this information available, there is some evidence that students either do not pay attention to it or do not take it all that seriously. Forty percent of students report receiving a crime report in an admissions packet, but 81% weren't sure if incoming students looked at the report when deciding on a school and only 6% said they thought students use it.<ref name="Steven2005">Steven, M. J., & Plummer, E. (2005). The clery act, campus safety and the views of assault victim advocates. College Student Affairs Journal, 25(1), 116-130. </ref>
To facilitate campus safety and security, many schools have a fully-functional police force, as well as victim advocate programs, criminal activity alerts, and sensor activated and restricted access dorms. As much effort as schools put towards safety, some of the responsibility does fall on the student. Many students are taking personal steps to insure their safety, including: traveling with another person around campus, not staying out late, and staying in safer parts of the surrounding town or city.
==Sexual Assault== While college campuses are generally quite safe, a concern female students, in particular, face is sexual assault. There are a variety of situations that increase the risks of sexual assault, and women should be aware of these (though of course victims are never responsible when such an assault takes place). For instance, accepting a ride with a male acquaintance, leaving a drink unattended at a bar or party, or allowing someone else to pour or buy you a drink can be risky situations as someone could take advantage of those situations to assault or drug someone. Some research suggests that female students do not perceive these as being risky.<ref name="Crawford2008">Crawford, Emily, Margaret O’Dougherty Wright, and Zachary Birchmeier. 2008. “Drug-Facilitated Sexual Assault: College Women’s Risk Perception and Behavioral Choices.” Journal of American College Health 57(3):261-272.</ref> While most women recognized the risks associated with having someone else pour them a drink, many did not recognize the risk of leaving a drink unattended. Additional education on college campuses about behaviors that may leave women open to these risks is warranted. While the perpetrators are at fault, until women are no longer at risk of victimization they should consider taking precautions.
==References== {{reflist}} {{BookCat}}
