|} As to resume the discussion, now extremely long of the primary proposal that has suffered several changes, themselves independent proposals that retroactively would affect the principal.
In accordance to what was previous discussed (read above), the first item that needs consensus is if the new "Autoreviewed users" access group (see [[Special:ListGroupRights]] for the permissions ), should be adopted on Wikibooks (answering the issue raised by Adrignola above). Because this would alter the rest of the proposals and so this item is given primacy.
Maintaining "Autoreviewed users" access group would permit a distinct access group whose edits will not change the review status of a page and no access to the rollback function of the reviewer groups.
As to address the issues discussed and close or continue addressing the dependent proposals, the community is therefore called to express opposition to keeping the "Autoreviewed users" access group. This discussion will last for 7 days after the last post on this thread. '''No opposition (or their restatement) will mean keeping the "Autoreviewed users" access group'''. The group will then have the community's support and we will proceed in giving it a function (as previously discussed) and the necessary requirements for attribution (the primary primary proposal by QuiteUnusual).
Please attempt to focus only on the specific topic and/or the viability of alternative approaches that would resolve most of the problems the community feels that having pages showing a pending reviewed status seems to cause. It would not only be welcomed but necessary to understand the real possibility of such solutions and how they may impact the use of the group.
Any issues not related with the discussion of this item, I (and I believe others) will gladly address on our own talk pages (but please read the previous posts above first). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 04:40, 18 April 2012 (UTC) Since no opposition was expressed we shall consider the existing [[Special:ListGroupRights]] validated by the community, a concern raised by Adrignola (the creation of the user group in itself is not specifically a high-impact decision but the next points regarding function and attribution will need to be properly announced).
We will now move on to the next point on the table regarding what use shall be given to the new usergroups. As advanced in the previous discussion some voiced opinions in defense of giving use to the "Autoreviewed users" usergroups as a stepping stone to reviewers and to better characterize the community confidence in those that do contribute content but do not wish to be auto-confirmed. That is we recognize a confidence that the content contributed is safe and within our project definitions and changes made by those users do not require a third person verification.
This of course permits to auto-promote to "Autoreviewed users" probably using a relaxed criteria based on what is now used for [[Wikibooks:Reviewers]] but this is not in discussion for now as there may be other proposal regarding the group function to be expressed.
This discussion will last for 7 days after the last post on this thread. '''No opposition (or their restatement) will mean using the "Autoreviewed users" access group as an intermediary access group in relation to the Reviewers''' (as proposed by myself). This is a discussion regarding appropriate function not the criteria granting "Autoreviewed users", if you have a better/different function for the usergroup put it forward. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 01:22, 30 April 2012 (UTC) : Panic, historically I have worked '''very''' hard at being polite in discussions, but, operating in that mode, it seems some messages here haven't been getting through to you. : Your strategy here seems to be to flood the thread with words until everyone is sick of the thread and boycotts it, and then claim that what you want has "consensus". There are books written mainly by 1 or several authors. These authors normally create an 'authors' page for their book and put their names there. But how can it be sure that this page is protected? In other words, how can these main authors keep their names credited? I suggest we should have another namespace, call it 'Author' or something like that, together with namespace 'Main' and 'Talk'. Pages of this namespace should be protected, only administrators or ones with enough privilege can edit. Once having enough evidence, the administrator can list the main authors of that book on the page. —Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/123.21.198.153|123.21.198.153]] ([[User talk:123.21.198.153|discuss]]) :You'd be best advised to suggest this at [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Proposals]], so that others can voice their opinions on it. That said, any page in any namespace can be protected such that only administrators can edit it, including authors pages within books in the main namespace. So a new namespace wouldn't necessarily be necessary to fulfill your proposal's goals. – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|discuss]] 16:14, 30 March 2012 (UTC) ::Hi Adrignola, I understand what you mean. Normally, the authors make a subpage named 'Authors' to their book and put its link in the first page (for example, in the Table of Contents). Of course the first page of that book is not protected, so anyone can ''delete'' that link (delete a link, not a page), make a new subpage and link to that! A new namespace next to the Talk namespace of the book can achieve 2 goals: its 'link' to the book can not be deleted, and its content can not be changed, until the administrators think there's enough evidence to do so. —Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/123.21.39.228|123.21.39.228]] ([[User talk:123.21.39.228|discuss]]) ::: Two thoughts, for what they're worth. :::* Once a name is (legitimately) on an authors subpage, the same counter-vandalism techniques that suffice elsewhere should suffice there. :::* There is a complete and indelible record of contributors to a book in its pages' revision histories. Authors subpages are generally less complete, as not all contributors sign the authors page — even if they contribute significantly; I generally don't, for example, because authors subpages seem to have a mild flavor of ownership about them. ::: --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 05:57, 31 March 2012 (UTC) :::: If I had a penny for each time that argument "There is a complete and indelible record of contributors to a book in its pages' revision histories" is thrown around as quick way to address the issue of authorship I would be a very rich man. Edit histories are useful but not by any means a complete, comprehensible and indelible record. I have discussed this endlessly and you as an administrator know that it is a failed argument, it could be hard to make contributions indelible but by intention or by a unforeseeable sequence of mishaps it can happen. :::: There is a intrinsic usefulness to know those that have rights over the works, the rational is the same for instance on why patents can only be signed by their inventors. There is much to hate around the issue of copyright and intellectual property in general but it is a disservice to all and even a possible reason why the project does not attract more authors the way the issue is constantly dismissed and not properly addressed by Wikimedia. Ultimately only the copyright holders can enforce the licenses and relicense the works, signing one's own work is a mater of responsibility and pride for the work done, that becomes even of primal importance in this intangible medium we use for our creations. Authorship is not attributed it is earned and claimed (with exceptions to legal requirements). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 06:18, 31 March 2012 (UTC) :::: Hi Pi zero, ones editing the book are not necessarily its author, so the revision history has no help. For example, I obtain permission to publish a book from its author, my work is simply copying and reformatting the book so that it appears well on Wikibooks. I am not its author. If I make an author subpage, there's no guarantee that the name of the original author remains unchanged. And if I make a link to that page, there's no guarantee that it will not be deleted and replaced by someone. —Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/123.21.213.250|123.21.213.250]] ([[User talk:123.21.213.250|discuss]]) As noted on every edit, people must agree that a hyperlink or URL is sufficient attribution. I think attributions in the form of a hyperlink or URL in the bibliography or further reading section of a book should be all that is done. I think all Author pages should then be deleted. I think books must be deleted if the authors of a prior work in which the book is based does not agree that a hyperlink or URL is sufficient attribution. An even stricter interpretation is possible where authors of prior works must agree that a hyperlink or URL back to the book on Wikibooks is sufficient attribution. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 12:22, 31 March 2012 (UTC) :How do you defend the copyright and the license outside of wikibooks, and what about all the necessary attribution that is required to compatible licensed work that was/is imported to our project ? :I'm kicking myself for entering yet again this type of discussion with you but I would like to see your response to these questions since they clearly can't be done within your vision. :It is worth mentioning that the removal of the authors page violates the existing licensing, but your vision if ever got any support from the community could be enforced on new works, even on imports (at least that would solve some, if not all copyright issues since then all imports would have to be verifiable as complying the requirement of limited acknowledgment). :I believe that if realized it would be the proverbial straw in the back of the camel for the project... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 12:36, 31 March 2012 (UTC) ::''Chiming in like I've been here for awhile''.. Interesting topic, but I think the largest problem with this is that a wikibook can never in theory be completed. This is a stark difference with books here versus a published work appearing at Wikisource, where there is clear attribution. Another problem is determining how much contribution to a book constitutes authorship. ::What would be the benefit of listing a name on an author page of a book that linked to an author ns, versus linking to the users page?- [[User:Theornamentalist|Theornamentalist]] ([[User talk:Theornamentalist|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Theornamentalist|contribs]]) 13:07, 31 March 2012 (UTC) :::Not to mention that the copyright of contributions and over the global work also varies from the origin of the contributor, there are significant differences between jurisdictions. On the project the location of the servers guides the legal requirements for compliance but works are not created only to reside on the server. Books that are usable (even if I fully agree with you that the objective is ultimately toward never-ending perfectionism and mutation), if properly published that version/revision can be moved to Wikisource. :::As for the how much contribution constitutes authorship is also another interesting subject, I have had several discussions about it in the past, but since there are those that still defend views like Darklama, that I blame Wikimedia because it fails to properly address the subject. I do not think at this time one could properly address it by ourselves. I wonder how does Commons deal with the copyright attribution of derivative works, in particular of works they also hold the "original"... :::More than legal matters, these issues are about expectations, the expectations of those contributing to the project. :::I had a very hard time making clear the distinction between ownership and control, and I fully understand that there is a minority that would like to make all content public domain. But they fail to comprehend that in that way no one can defend the freedom of the content, that is also part of the interests of the authors/copyright holders next to the right of acknowledgment. These people often are not creators themselves or have not a long term view regarding the works, only seeing the works as existing on this project right now. This is something hard to empathize for anyone with vested interest on his/hers creation. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 14:10, 31 March 2012 (UTC) :: Copyright and license for books is defended by complaining to [[m:OTRS|OTRS]]. I think any work or license is incompatible with Wikibooks if attributions beyond a hyperlink or URL is necessary for text contributions. In the more stricter interpretation any work or license is incompatible with Wikibooks if attribution beyond a hyperlink or URL to the book on Wikibooks for text contributions is necessary. People would probably have to deal with the jurisdiction issues if they tried to defend the copyright and license for books on their own. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 14:59, 31 March 2012 (UTC) ::: The OTRS serves to protect Wikimedia ([[meta:OTRS/info-en mission]]) not the works and in regards to copyright not even the users (a copyright infringer can be legally persecuted by actions on the Wikimedia projects, Wikimedia has no responsibility and will even be able to provide logs of the activity). In the requirements of attribution, and this is something we already discussed, the works license requires express agreement to it (some defend that a simple click-trough suffices) some like myself doubt this view, especially when using third party content and because of the volatility of not only the identity of users, but of the records themselves. Only copyright holders can relicense their content (USA with exception to Public Domain works). Copyright relinquishing has to be done by writing or terminus of copyright protection (USA). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 15:49, 31 March 2012 (UTC) This comment is a little unrelated to the last part of this discussion regarding copyright laws, but I'm going to write it anyway: I think Wikibooks should be clearly attributed to their author(s) on Wikibooks. You can expect people to fix a typo or right something to an encyclopedia without wanting attribution, but a book, even a Wikibook, is different. Writing a book is ''a lot of work'', and many more writers will be attracted to this project if they are attributed on the main page of the book in an obvious way. The point of Wikibooks it to make available books that are free to use and can be edited by anyone. But why shouldn't the writer be attributed, even if he or she does not own the copyright? For that matter, why shouldn't opinionated or non-neutral books be allowed? Wikibooks seems to me to be operating too much on the standards of Wikipedia, i.e. the standards of an encyclopedia. As long as the authors are attributed in a clear way on the front page, why not have the book express opinions, as long as the book is marked as a non-neutral book and you know who wrote it? A new namespace could even be created calle either "Essay" or "Opinion" or something similar, and leave the main namespace for text books. The main thing I'm saying here is that for people to want to write full-fledged books that they have no control over and do not profit from, this project will have to make some concessions to them (the writers) and give them credit and freedom in writing, and maybe even limited control over the Wikibook they write. [[User:Liam987|'''Liam987]]''' 10:14, 1 April 2012 (UTC) :The issue with having authors signing their work has two main problems. The one that was raised above by the proponent, the lack of protection for the information and the general lack of guidelines from Wikimedia linked to the unpreparedness of the administration to deal with the subject (verify claims, this is also observable when we deal for instance with claims of copyright violations, almost always we put the burden of prof on the contributor not on the copyright holder this is a fragility that can lead to preemptive deletion of valid content, since in case of doubt the path is deletion.) and having the required tools it would be an astronomical mess going through the history logs to verify that information (I think [[User:Robert Horning]] opened a ticked on that). :As you stated Wikibooks and Wikipedia are very distinct (the best match is indeed as I think someone said above Wikisource) in this regard, of legal protection of works and authors. I would go as far a stating that some articles go beyond simple factual information and probably also copyrightable, but that is something that is up for that project to handle. In any case I would expect that someone has to be listed as the owner of the rights over the work if not I do not see how they could actively enforce the project licensing... :On the issue of attribution every contributor the history logs do indeed satisfy it and are easier to maintain accurate (of course it would be extremely interesting to have a better listing of all edits on all pages of a work centralized) and the fact that the work is not simply a result of the authors should be stressed as recognition from all. This distinction is that authors must by legal requirements be listed in the work in whatever medium it is presented (IIRC the GFDL asks for the top 5 and the CCBYSA for 3) and it would be impractical to list all the names/ips of all editors to a work in that case a simply link to the Wikibook project could serve (and in the author pages I created this is done). :Regarding the changing of the scope of Wikibooks that is a distinct discussion that could be extended in the talk page of [[Wikibooks:What is Wikibooks?]] policy (this is valid also for the issue of Essays), but I note that non-neutral books can be created and the non-neutrality (POV) can be some what protected by stating it clearly on the scope of the book what and how it will cover the issue. :I also take the chance to clarify that authors (even Wikimedia and users) can profit from Wikibooks. That means that the author subpage is there, in the book, even if the link on the main page is removed. The only way you could "remove" it from the book would be to move every other page in the book to a new name leaving it behind. There is no way this kind of page move vandalism would not be spotted. I also agree that volunteers don't actively protect the "rights" of others. This discussion of the proposal seems to:
a) Not contradict or invalidate any of the views as expressed by Darklama (and in the past others), are not an opposition to the proposal but to the existence of the author pages, something that goes beyond what is being discussed, but has been objected above.
b) Since author pages exist and do, whatever view is defended, have a legal validity and serve a function, special consideration regarding their protection may be warranted. No one objected specifically to that.
c) It can be concluded that only those involved in the work (especially those making claims authorship/copyright ownership or using the pages to give the necessary legal or moral attributions to third parties or sources) have the capacity to fully respond or validate those edits. Putting the pages beyond the normal review process for accuracy or in works covering a large number of pages or activity a creating a great burden for anyone determining copyright ownership claims. My conclusion from the previous discussion.
d) That any decision resulting from the alteration of common practice should not be retroactive, generalized or be imposing beyond establishing a new set of guidelines regarding the handling of the type of content under discussion and validating administrative action to protect their content. My conclusion from the previous discussion.
e) That the commonly agreed solution, from all the proposals made on how to handle the issue, would be to protect editing of these pages upon administrative request by anyone with the reviewer flag to only Wikibookians with that same flag.
I further add a request that [[Wikibooks:Ownership]] be updated at the end of the discussion (and its edit history be revised) as to reflect this procedure, since some subjects had and are already been discussed there and that Wikibooks:Ownership page be moved to the Help namespace (since we will not be defining a policy or a guideline) but establishing a common community understanding of the subject matter regarding the function of the these types of pages (copyright information). It should continue to maintain a well written distinction between copyright ownership and editorial/content control and a clarification of author/copyright holder versus contributor. Any objection or alteration to this request does not invalidate the proposal but I feel that it would help Wikibookians to have a clear source of understanding regarding the subject. This of course can be proposed independently if people find that it needs further discussion.
Another request, that also does not impact the proposal if opposed is that any pages regarding copyright should in the future, and retroactively as detected, be put in a specific category, possibly a subcategory of Wikibooks copyright. I believe that there will not be any objection to the categorization but possibly to the name or location. I hope no one gets distracted on this as the label/location in not as important as the functionality to ease the identification of those type of pages. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 00:59, 5 April 2012 (UTC) : Here again, I do not perceive a consensus where you appear to be claiming such exists. This discussion has gotten way too long to read, frankly; I look at the very top, where I see "There are books written mainly by 1 or several authors. These authors normally create an 'authors' page for their book and put their names there. But how can it be sure that this page is protected? In other words, how can these main authors keep their names credited?", and my basic answer is still that there is no reason to protect this page in any manner it isn't already protected by our counter-vandalism measures (specifically flaggedrevs, though there's a simultaneous proposal here that could interfere with the efficacy of flaggedrevs). If there were a reason to give it extra protection in some cases (unlikely, but ''if''), there would be no reason to create a whole namespace for the purpose. So I'm the one defending the point of a proposal that I didn't advance but since I consider the core point valid and worth pursuing I will again restate something that I've many times spoken about (and others). :::: I can't briefly state a complex issue, and I know I tend to be verbose so bear with me... :::: 1) Regarding the argument that counter-vandalism measures do not suffice. - It would be obvious by previous copyvio discussions the issues we have in defining authors and obtaining the right information most of the time. I'm here since 2004 and have probably seen more discussions than you. You can check them out easily or even look at the RfD for the C++ Programming (in regards to how the copyright issue was dealt). There are also few copyvios lingering in the backlog of deletions that supports the issue of how hard it is to determine and verify copyright ownership. :::: Regarding the maintenance of the Copyright notices on books it would be instructive for you to do a search on the project, and simply consider their validity, we have works that still have the GFDL as their license (not that a book's license is specific for the aggregation). One task of the administration upon the conversion to the dual licensing should have been the examination of this notices if a) no copyright owners was directly licensing the work they should be removed (with care to any acknowledgments that would be required to be maintained) b) determine the date of the GFDL use (published revision of the work) and if done before the date limit, simply update to the CCBYSA30. c) if the date is after the GFDL examination contact the copyright owners or editors and get the authorization to change to the CCBYSA30 and risk of having to delete the work if some content was imported that was licensed only under the GFDL (with limitations) since the license was not compatible. To my knowledge none of this was ever done. I mention this to demonstrate that the subject of copyright and licensing is not dealt seriously or with consistency and the required Wikimedia supervision. :::: It is also extremely difficult if not impossible to verify copyright ownership claims, that is those that add themselves (or others) as authors, copyright owners and to lists of acknowledgments. There is not only a general lack of knowledge by Wikibookians about the requirements or distinctions but as discussed these pages are left open to even to unregistered users (I would even see a need for Autoconfirmation to be able to create and edit such legal notices), and so the information that should be more valuably protected that the edit history logs is often corrupted or misused, possibly creating problems in the long run. Having as was proposed during the thread a greater requirement on creating these pages can only be of benefit to the project. :::: Who polices this pages/type of information I rarely see anyone really taking interest in them besides the most dedicated contributors to the project. This information is not only legally useful, but has historical interest. Authors and those that donate works or permit us to reuse should rest assured that their rights are protected. I do not see how the project can evolve if we continue on the path to indifference of this matters. :::: As a practical example consider the issue of [[Communication Networks]] and how can you verify that the information is correct (it is possible but the amount of work required is not something that the project can or should bear). Ultimately any dispute about copyrights can have tree outcomes a legal litigation between those making the claims, or with a contributor or result in removal of the work because ultimately every contributor is anonymous to a vast degree. :::: We have to acknowledge that this pages are indeed special, more important that the disclaimers we put in some work and more that most would like to admit that the history logs, so what is the issue in granting them better protection? :::: 2) Regarding Authors pages, ''of the sort described at the top of this thread'', being irrelevant to copyright. - By making that remark you show that you have little to no knowledge on the issue. Any phrasing that invokes rights, establish procedures or rules and invokes the law in writing constitutes a legal document. A legal instrument is simply a legal document that is unequivocally attributed to its author(s). Both our licensees require a written statement agreeing to them as to become a legal instrument. Without entering the discussion of the click-through, the use of the direct subscription of the license(s) is important to protect the work, making it clear that the work is subject to copyright, and deter infringement or plagiarism. Also to provide a means of identifying the copyright owner(s); for instance for relicensing purposes and validation of the content. :::: These statements are not only useful (to the project, to the work and to those that claim it) but a right of those that contribute copyrightable content. If you have done the search I indicated you will have noticed a large variety of examples of people that have used this right. Ultimately having them make the statement does not infringe on anyone else's rights unless they are in violation of copyright and then a problem that we have to handle. :::: These legal document are not required to be in a specific page or section (like the disclaimers we normally use) but only for convenience they should be listed together. :::: As your view that it is a matter of vanity pages, this is false by the reasons above but because people should be proud and take responsibility for their actions. The claim of ownership makes the content safer, to be valid and not a copyvio (since those making false claims could indeed get into legal trouble). In fact not defining copyright ownership is the shameful option as you are abdicating to give protection to it, in that case it would be better to give your copyrights to Wikimedia so they can in the future defend the work or relicense it. (Similar to how some people give their rights to the FSF when releasing Open Source software). :::: Some interesting examples [[Scouting/BSA/First Aid Merit Badge]], [[Marijuana Cultivation/Introduction]], [[Linter SQL RDBMS]] (this one is extremely confusing since it is unclear if it is a replication of the software license or if it covers the work), [[Engineering Acoustics]] (redundant but not wrong), [[Strengths-Based Social Work Practice/Copyleft]] (confusing Copyleft in the name of the page, then he is both copyright owner and contributor) and [[General Engineering Introduction/Communication/Ground rules]] (I leave this one as an exercise to you...) --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 04:52, 20 April 2012 (UTC) I have no doubts that copyright and licenses are taken seriously by Administrators. Fortunately Wikibooks has pages that address most copyright and license concerns. Unfortunately Wikibooks does not for Authorship. Compared with copyright lawyers, Wikibooks Administrators are amateurs on the subject of copyright, licenses, and authorship. Even when people think they know whats what, things can go wrong. [http://www.informationweek.com/news/development/java/232900594 Oracle vs Google over whether programming languages and APIs can be copyrighted] or [http://tap.usf.edu/news/major-textbook-publishers-file-copyright-lawsuit-against-open-education-resource-provider/ Major Textbook Publishers vs Open Education Startup claiming copyright violations over similarities], for example. I agree that a formal position by the community about Authorship would be very useful and helpful at encouraging people to contribute. I doubt whether Author pages in any location makes sense when neither a policy or guideline exists for people to follow or be guided by, and no community decision exists that mandates their use, how and when they are to be used, when and if its appropriate or inappropriate for anyone who contributes to Wikibooks to claim Authorship for a book, when and if its appropriate or inappropriate to add Acknowledgments for Authors who contribute directly to Wikibooks, what forms of acknowledgments/attribution for third-party works are acceptable and unacceptable, when a third-party work is used who must prove or verify permission or lack of permission and what are acceptable and unacceptable ways to do so, whether all Contributors are Authors, and where acknowledgments/attributions should be placed. I think Author pages effectively discourage people from contributing because there is no policy or guideline that describe what it means to Author a book at Wikibooks, so some people assume the ramifications are that Authors have total and complete control over the development of books. I think Wikibooks will continue to see decreased activity if an Author namespace is created without addressing the core issues first. I agree that Author pages are vanity pages because anyone may use them for any purpose since the core issues haven't been addressed yet. I think by addressing the core issues, whether to move forward with an Authors namespace will become clear. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 15:39, 20 April 2012 (UTC) :Don't get it. I do not see this as an administration only issue, it is not expected that administrators know more about what is what in legal matters than any other Wikibookian. Then you classify admins as amateurs on the subject of copyright, note that these amateurs are required to, in isolation and without logs delete works they judge as violating copyright law (something that I've been extremely vocal against in the past, requesting a log keeping, but that is another discussion). This is just to point out that Wikibookians are expected to exert and interpret the law (even as to be able to contribute) and it is a special requirement for adminship to be able to enforce legal dictates. :Then you propose that the community, that is, the active community (mostly constituted by the above mentioned amateurs) establish a position. This clearly is not possible, especially as an enforcible policy, in not wanted (by your own recognition of lack of full understanding of the subject or even an ability to consensually decide on it) not or even legal (we can't locally, rewrite the law or go against it). Legal matters should be decided by Wikimedia's legal department, the community has no power to rewrite the law and should be extremely carefully when providing their own interpretations of the law. Note that those that do not understand the legal matters should restrain themselves to act on this subjects (like in any aspect that one find oneself out-of-depth, in particular you proposal that the copyright statements should just be deleted put you on that boat). :The claim of ownership of copyrights (not particularly authorship) is a legal right, the notice is itself not a legal required (debatable, due to the wording of the licenses, particularly the GFDL, but I tend to agree). Even if copyright law as abolished the use of the copyright statement, in this case it is useful for users, contributors (in particular required for attribution purposes) and ultimately Wikimedia. The only possible way to resolve the issue would be to force granting all the rights to Wikimedia, and this would be damaging to the project or move all works into the public domain, but by the decision of Wikimedia to use specific licensing, the copyright issues has to some point been considered, and the licenses establishes some guidelines (even if not completely clear and in view of our format). :This of course does not invalidate that the community provides some clarifications, like you propose, we can however inform of best procedures and on disparate views, without establishing a legal interpretation. This has been attempted in the past. :As for your statement that Author pages effectively discourage people from contributing, I accept it as your personal view, not as a fact, personally I do not know but I note that most books that have a copyright statement tend to be more complete and mature that others that people contributing have not taken responsibility over. :I oppose the idea of an Author namespace, the possibility to grant copyright and other legal statements and disclaimers statements a specific location and protection (page protection) seem however a simple, rational and non intrusive thing to do. With no negative implications and solving some problems and eases maintenance work. I also do not see as positive an out of proportion treatment to this issue, because most less knowledgeable Wikibookians would indeed see it as a sort of special recognition of their pears, like adminiship was seen in the past. This is not what we should aim for nor for an increase on claims of copyright ownership by those that do not fully understand the implications. Just an extra proper protection and a consistency in dealing with them is what the proponent seems to be aiming, and that I support. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 13:04, 22 April 2012 (UTC)
|} As to resume and conclude the discussion, now extremely long of the primary proposal regarding the creation of an Author namespace to protect copyright claims and attributions made by an unsigned or unregistered user and taking in consideration the opinions expressed on the subject. I move that the proposal as initially state should be negated as not gathering the consensus.
A subsequent alternative proposal, taking in consideration what has been said, will occur afterwards as to provide communal validation for requests of page protection regarding copyright and legal sensitive notices, that will address partially the concerns of the initial proponent.
This request will be open for participation until 7 days after the last post on this thread. '''No opposition (or their restatement) will mean that the community does not support the creation of a new Author namespace''' (as initial proposed). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 01:50, 30 April 2012 (UTC)

[[File:Stop x nuvola with clock.svg|40px|left|link=]] '''[[Wikibooks:Blocking policy|You cannot edit]] for 1 day due to vandalism'''. You are welcome to contribute constructively when editing privileges are restored. You may appeal this action with a reasonable argument by adding the text {{tlx|unblock|Your reason here}} below.

A Kexi database can hold 5 types of objects: tables, queries, forms, reports, and scripts.
A table is a grid that holds data (for instance, the patrons of a library.) The horizontal rows of the grid are called "records", and contain information on a single entity (e.g. one patron). The vertical columns hold a piece data of a certain ''type'' (e.g. a patron's phone number), and are called "fields".
A query creates sets of data pulled from one or more tables. Various operators and functions may be used to manipulate the data. For instance, in a library database, you could take the "patrons" table (which also has data on which books are checked out), and correlate it with the "books" table (which has book titles and due dates), to form a new table that holds information on all patrons that still have overdue books.
Forms provide a simple, familiar interface for editing and viewing the database.
Kexi scripts can be written in JavaScript, Python, or any other scripting language supported by Kross (the KDE scripting framework). {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
==Casual gaming== The rise of casual gaming, or relatively cheaper pc games has grown quickly with casual games representing 2.25 billion dollars in revenue in 2008. Casual games include hits such as [[w:Diner Dash|Diner Dash]] , [[w:Feeding Frenzy (video game)|Feeding Frenzy]] , and [[w:Bejeweled|Bejeweled]] and have a demographic which is 74% female. Social and casual gaming is expanding rapidly. In 2011 Social and casual gaming received about half of all game related investments.<ref>http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/162929/Social_casual_market_dominated_game_investments_in_2011_report_says.php</ref> casual games however oftern operate under the try before you buy business model. Users download a game then purchase a code to unlock the entirety of it's features. There is however especially in the PC arena, the problem of online piracy eroding profits. The game Ricochet:Infinity, had a player base in which 92% of users pirated the game. The piracy problem has lead to a revenue model which derives much of it's revenue from in-game ads and microtransactions in freemium games rather than from initial purchase price.
== FarmVille == Farmville, is a farming simulations social network game released in 2009 by Zynga. It surpassed 80 million monthly active users making it the most actively played game in world wide, until it was later surpassed by similar Zynga game CityVille. The farmville user base has since deflated, in large part due to spam curbing efforts by Facebook reducing notifications to invite friends to participate. The revenue model for farmville comes from the purchasing of ingame items for Farmville cash, which can be bought using currency which can either be attained in game or instantaneously for cash. The strong network externalities, free entry and ease of access and automatic advertising brought about its rapid success. By integrating with facebook, it became much easier to establish a social relations in farmville. It also exhibits several psychological hooks which help engage the user base to the level where people start paying for in-game assets. For one many of the ways in which items are required are random and require a very intensive use of farm cash. You get between 5-6 farmville dollars for a U.S. dollar depending on the number purchased. They are used to buy decorative items for a farm. There is a slot machine as well as several other methods which give random rewards. They can also be used to purchase in came coins in order to speed progress through the game and customization. Farmville requires that you add a certain number of neighbors in order to expand, this provides strong network externalities making the desire to expand great. Neighbors can tend each others crops and send gifts to one another. The player base of Farmville is largely nonpaying however, and a small fraction generate most of the revenue from Farmville.
==ZT online== The advantage of freemium model is that it enables free entry, but the micro-transaction model can allow users to spend extreme amounts in order to maintain their standing in a game. One notorious instance of this is in the Chinese MMORPG ZT(ZhengThu) online. ZT Online was the most popular Chinese online game in 2007-2008{{cn}}<!--<ref>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ZT_Online</ref>-->. While there is not fee ofr entry, all items are gained by opening chests with keys that cost money real world money. Once chests are opened a roulette style indicator randomly selects the items from a an alluring list containing items of varying degrees. The rarest items having a very low probabilities of selection. This creates gambling mechanic for virtual goods, and an addicting and stratified power structure. Rewards for opening the most chests in a day further spur on users to spend large amounts on the game.
In the third quarter of 2007 ZT online had an average revenue per user of an impressive RMB 305.2 48.41 dollars<ref>http://investorshub.advfn.com/boards/board.aspx?board_id=11228#</ref> This is particularly high for a freemium game and represents the fact that micro-transactions are an integral part of playing the game, woven in with the addicting psychology of gambling.
==League of Legends== League of legends is an action strategy game released by Riot games in 2009. While matches take place between teams of 5(sometimes 3) in independent instances, there are several persistent elements to the game, such as summoner level runes and accumulated champions. Customizable character skins which can only be bought for the games virtual currency. AS with many virtual currencies, the appeal is twofold, not only does it add a small degree of separation from real world money, but virtual currency is generally purchased in denominations that differ from the prices of in-game assets. This results in an increased desire to spend with the sometimes perpetually left over money. The System is setup so runes, which raise the statistics of in-game characters, are purchased via influence points, a currency gained solely through in game play(Although boosts which multiply the amount gained from play can be purchased for riot points). There is also a second in game currency, riot points which can be only be purchased using real money. For each match the player selects a champion with which to play, they can either select from one of 10 free champions, rotated randomly on a weekly basis, or from a champion they have purchased. Champions can be purchased either through riot points or influence points. Purchasing them through influence points however is extremely time consuming and detracts from one's ability to purchase stat raising runes. This inspires players to spend money to permanently unlock champions they desire to play, as well as skins to customize the champions their favorites. Since skins can only be bought using riot points, players are paying to express their identity, sometimes $10 or more per skin. This along with a constant stream of new champions allows for some players to pay large amounts of money while others can buy few or no champions. ==Zynga== The company behind farmville, CityVille is one of the largest social gaming companies. In Feb 2012 they reported a revenue of $311 million with an average of $2 per user. With only about 3% of the users paying,<ref>http://mashable.com/2012/03/23/zynga-economics/</ref> Zynga relies on a small segment of large spenders to generate the it's revenue while the rest of the users provide the competitive environment will take place. ==Riot games== In order to foster a more competitive atmosphere as well as increase the overall play base, Riot games has invested heavily in the competitive scene. With a $5million dollar prize pool announced for the second season of League of legends, including a $2 million dollar finals. This move is designed to grow the userbase for league of legends as well as increase the number of hardcore users as they contribute largely per user in order to remain competitive. In February of 2011 Riot games was purchased by Tencent, a Chinese internet holdings company for $400 million dollars.
==The stigma of paying for success== The important aspect of League of Legends is that while many trappings of success can be bought it has avoided the stigma associated with too much influence from money in the game. Stat changes from runes are only influenced marginally by the spending of money, and champions in the free rotation come from the list of buyable one's so there's no inherent disadvantage in paying for progress. This has prevented a mass disuasion of free users as one would see in games such as Zt online. The important part is to balance the act of encouraging payment while still providing incentives for free users to say on board, since a large player base is necessary to sustain itself in the tippy online market.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{BookCat}}

This page provides advice on how to install the MediaWiki-to-LaTeX converter wb2pdf in Fedora. It is wholly based in [[en:User:Duplode|my]] own experience with F16, so take it with a grain of salt and adapt the details to your system if need be. You will likely want to check [[:de:Benutzer:Dirk_Huenniger/wb2pdf|the main wb2pdf page]], with download links and usage instructions, and in particular [[:de:Benutzer:Dirk_Huenniger/wb2pdf/ubuntu|the installation guide for Ubuntu]], from which this page was originally derived.
== The TeXLive 2011 repository ==
The default Fedora 16 repositories carry an outdated set of TeXLive packages which lacks many things we will need for wb2pdf. Before installing the packages, it is necessary to install the test repository for TeXLive 2011 (see this [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Features/TeXLive Fedora Project page] for details and instructions for Fedora versions other than 16). In Fedora 16, run:
su -c 'rpm -i http://jnovy.fedorapeople.org/texlive/2011/packages.fc16/texlive-release.noarch.rpm' su -c 'yum clean all'
If you already have the older TeXLive installed, you will also need to
su -c 'yum update'
== Installing packages ==
Next, we will install all packages needed for building and running wb2pdf, including the TexLive ones. Here is the yum command, in one shot:
su -c 'yum install subversion python3 python3-tkinter ImageMagick librsvg2 fontforge-devel ghc ghc-regex-compat-devel ghc-HTTP-devel ghc-split-devel ghc-MissingH-devel cabal-install texlive-scheme-basic texlive-collection-latexrecommended texlive-collection-latexextra texlive-collection-fontsrecommended texlive-collection-fontsextra texlive-collection-games texlive-collection-humanities texlive-collection-science texlive-arabtex texlive-cjk texlive-collection-langcjk texlive-collection-langcyrillic texlive-collection-langgreek texlive-collection-langvietnamese texlive-cm-super texlive-gnu-freefont wqy-zenhei-fonts'
The same packages, in a more readable presentation:
su -c 'yum install subversion python3 python3-tkinter ImageMagick librsvg2 fontforge-devel' su -c 'yum install ghc ghc-regex-compat-devel ghc-HTTP-devel ghc-split-devel ghc-MissingH-devel cabal-install' su -c 'yum install texlive-scheme-basic texlive-collection-latexrecommended texlive-collection-latexextra' su -c 'yum install texlive-collection-fontsrecommended texlive-collection-fontsextra texlive-collection-games' su -c 'yum install texlive-collection-humanities texlive-collection-science texlive-arabtex texlive-cjk' su -c 'yum install texlive-collection-langcjk texlive-collection-langcyrillic texlive-collection-langgreek' su -c 'yum install texlive-collection-langvietnamese texlive-cm-super texlive-gnu-freefont wqy-zenhei-fonts'
(This list was inferred from the [[:de:Benutzer:Dirk_Huenniger/wb2pdf/ubuntu|Ubuntu instructions]]; compare with that one if you find some package is missing - and if so I kindly ask you to correct the commands here.)
There are two packages which are not in the Fedora repositories. ghc-hxt will be automatically installed by Cabal (the Haskell package system) when you build wb2pdf; there is also unifont, which will be dealt with in a later step.
== Building wb2pdf ==
Next, we will get the sources and build wb2pdf:
svn co https://wb2pdf.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/wb2pdf wb2pdf cd wb2pdf/trunk cabal update cabal install cd src python3 makelinuxbins.py
Note that I am assuming a per-user (as opposed to global) installation of wb2pdf by cabal.
== Building and installing megafont ==
wb2pdf requires a set of fonts, called megafont, which is a combination of the unifont, FreeSerif ans wqy-zenhei fonts. We need to build and install megafont to the LaTeX tree. wb2pdf comes with a python script which help building megafont. First, however, you will need to download unifont, which is not in the Fedora repositories. You can get it from [http://unifoundry.com/unifont.html this page] (the first link to a ttf.gz file). Extract it to the <tt>font</tt> sudirectory of the svn trunk and rename the ttf file to unifont.ttf .
The script for installing megafont is in the same <tt>font</tt> subdirectory. To run it, then, do:
cd ../font su -c 'python3 installunifont_fedora.py'
The script will install the fonts to the LaTeX tree for local additions, as set in your system by the file /usr/share/texlive/texmf/web2c/texmf.cnf . You can find it with:
kpsewhich --var-value TEXMFLOCAL
== Updating the TeX tree ==
(This section is based in information from [http://www.tug.org/fonts/fontinstall.html this page from the TeX Users Group].)
Finally, we need to register the megafont fonts in the TeX tree. To do that, run the following commands:
su -c 'texhash' updmap --enable Map=megafont.map su -c 'texhash'
Again, note that the updmap step is being performed locally, and not globally.
wb2pdf is now ready to run:
cd ../src/ python3 gui.py
And that's it - for further instructions, see the [[:de:Benutzer:Dirk Huenniger/wb2pdf/manual|wb2pdf manual]].

Dear Wikibookians,
No doubt some of you are familiar with the free college courses available on [http://Saylor.org Saylor.org]. Much like the Wikimedia community, we are committed to providing free and accessible education for everyone with internet access. At Saylor, we combine some of our custom-created educational materials with materials that are already available throughout the internet. However, because we sometimes use links to third party materials, those sections of our courses are not entirely sustainable. The Saylor Wikibooks Project is a way for you to help minimize that threat. We’ve uploaded a number of our course outlines to Wikibooks in the hope that you all will contribute to our effort. Our course outlines have been developed by our consultant professors by studying a collection of syllabi of relevant courses from various traditional brick and mortar institutions. This guarantees that our students will be provided the same learning opportunity as a student enrolled in a traditional institution. We believe that we have created the best structure for our courses, which optimizes the information that students would be expected to know. By creating openly licensed content that fits in with Saylor’s established course outlines, (in the form of Wikibooks’ textbooks), you can add to the ever-expanding body of wiki material, while simultaneously improving the sustainability of our courses.

Thanks for your help,
The Saylor Team If you'd like to learn more about the project please visit [[User:Thomas_Simpson]] '''Summary''' [[File:Onion Cells.jpg|thumb|right]] The cell is the fundamental unit of life; in fact, the smallest living organisms are composed of a single cell. Despite their small size, cells are far from simple, and we have only recently begun to understand just how complex they are. This text will present you with a detailed overview of a cell’s main components and functions. The text is roughly organized into four major areas: the cell membrane, cell nucleus, cell cycle, and cell interior. We will approach most of these topics straightforwardly, from a molecular and structural point of view. '''Global Learning Outcomes''' * Explain what a eukaryotic cell is, identify the components of the cell, and describe how a cell functions. * Explain how cell membranes are formed. * Identify the general mechanisms of transport across cell membranes. * List the different ways in which cells communicate with one another—specifically, via signaling pathways. * Define what the extracellular matrix is composed of in different cells and how the extracellular matrix is involved in forming structures in specific tissues. * List the components of the cell’s cytoskeleton and explain how the cytoskeleton is formed and how it directs cell movements. * Explain the fundamentals of gene expression and describe how gene expression is regulated at the protein level. * Define and explain the major cellular events involved in mitosis and cytokinesis. * Identify the major cellular events that occur during meiosis. * Describe the eukaryotic cell cycle and identify the events that need to occur during each phase of the cell cycle. * Identify all of the major organelles in eukaryotic cells and their respective major functions. __TOC__ ==[[/Review of Basic Concepts/]]== Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Identify the functions of major organic molecules. * Understand hydrophilic and hydrophobic bonds and their respective roles in cells (particularly in terms of cell-membrane structure). * Understand the four levels of protein structures and be able to identify which structure is referred to in a given example. * Understand the relationship between free energy and the direction of a reaction.
:1.1 [[/Biology/]] ::1.1.1 [[/Amino Acids/]] ::1.1.2 [[/Four Levels of Protein Structures/]] ::1.1.3 [[/Carbohydrates/]] ::1.1.4 [[/ATP/]] ::1.1.5 [[/DNA and RNA/]] ::1.1.6 [[/Free Energy and ATP/]] ==[[/The Cell Membrane/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Know and identify the components of membranes. * Understand how these components affect membrane properties. * Identify types of membrane transport (specific pumps and channels) and understand the role of various molecules and ions (e.g. sodium, calcium) in this transport.
:2.1 [[/Membrane Components/]] ::2.1.1 [[/Lipids, Sphingolipids, Glycolipids/]] ::2.1.2 [[/Sterols/]] :2.2 [[/Fluid Mosaic Model/]] :2.3 [[/Membrane Pumps/]] ::2.3.1 [[/Glycophorin and Bacteriorhodopsin/]] ::2.3.2 [[/ATP-Driven Pumps/]] ::2.3.3 [[/ABC (ATP-Binding Cassette) Transporters/]] :2.4 [[/Membrane Channels/]] ::2.4.1 [[/Sodium and Potassium Channels/]] ::2.4.2 [[/Leak Channels and Membrane Potential/]] ::2.4.3 [[/Water Channel/]] :2.5 [[/Membrane Physiology/]] ::2.5.1 [[/Glucose Transport in Intestines/]] ::2.5.2 [[/Synthesis of ATP in Mitochondria/]] ==[[/Cell Signaling/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Distinguish between different signaling pathways. * Identify the function and roles of different kinds of receptors in the cell-signaling process. * Understand the steps involved in signaling pathways and determine, when given certain conditions, what step of the process will be affected.
:3.1 [[/Basic Types of Cell Signaling/]] ::3.1.1 [[/Juxtacrine Signaling/]] ::3.1.2 [[/Paracrine Signaling/]] ::3.1.3 [[/Endocrine Signaling/]] :3.2 [[/Receptors/]] ::3.2.1 [[/G Protein-Coupled Receptors (GPCRs)/]] ::3.2.2 [[/Receptor Tyrosine Kinases (RTKs)/]] ::3.2.3 [[/Cytokine Receptors/]] ::3.2.4 [[/Receptor Serine/Threonine Kinases, Guanylyl Cyclase Receptors, and the TNF (Tumor Necrosis Factor) Receptor Family/]] :3.3 [[/Reversible Phosphorylation/]] ::3.3.1 [[/Kinase and Phosphatase Cycle/]] ::3.3.2 [[/Serine and Threonine Phosphorylation/]] ::3.3.3 [[/Tyrosine Phosphorylation/]] ::3.3.4 [[/Regulation of Kinases and Phosphatases/]] ::3.3.5 [[/GTPase (Guanosine TriPhosphatase) Cycle/]] ::3.3.6 [[/Trimeric G (Guanosine) Protein Cycle/]] :3.4 [[/Secondary Messengers/]] ::3.4.1 [[/Cyclic Nucleotides/]] ::3.4.2 [[/Lipid-Derived Secondary Messengers and Calcium/]] ::3.4.3 [[/Nitric Oxide/]] :3.5 [[/Integrated Signaling Pathways/]] ::3.5.1 [[/Light Signal Transduction Inside Photoreceptor Cells/]] ::3.5.2 [[/Epinephrine and Norepinephrine Pathways Inside Muscle/]] ::3.5.3 [[/MAPK (Mitogen-Activated Protein Kinase) Pathway/]] :3.6 [[/Synaptic Transmission at Neuromuscular Junction/]] ==[[/The Extracellular Matrix (ECM)/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Answers questions about ECM molecules, including their functions and where each type of molecule is most common. * Understand the functions of different kinds of adhesion molecules. * Distinguish between types of intercellular junctions.
:4.1 [[/ECM Molecules/]] ::4.1.1 [[/Collagen/]] ::4.1.2 [[/Elastic Fibers/]] ::4.1.3 [[/Proteoglycans, Glycosaminoglycans, and Hyaluronan/]] ::4.1.4 [[/Adhesive Glycoproteins/]] :4.2 [[/Basal Lamina/]] :4.3 [[/Cellular Adhesion Molecules (CAMs)/]] :4.4 [[/Intercellular Junctions/]] ::4.4.1 [[/Tight Junctions/]] ::4.4.2 [[/Gap Junctions/]] ::4.4.3 [[/Adherens Junctions and Desmosomes/]] :4.5 [[/ECM and Connective Tissue/]] ::4.5.1 [[/Loose Connective Tissue (LCT)/]] ::4.5.2 [[/Dense Connective Tissue (DCT)/]] ==[[/The Cytoskeleton/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Understand the different roles of actin, tubulin, and intermediate filaments. * Understand the properties and functions of actin, tubulin, and intermediate filaments. * Understand the means through which cytoskeletal molecules are formed. * Be able to determine which cytoskeletal molecule or process has been disrupted when given an example of a particular cellular problem or lack of function. * Understand the relationship between cytoskeletal elements and cell/intracellular movements.
:5.1 [[/Cytoskeleton Molecules/]] ::5.1.1 [[/Actin and Myosin/]] ::5.1.2 [[/Microtubules and Tubulin/]] ::5.1.3 [[/Intermediate Filaments/]] :5.2 [[/Actin Family/]] ::5.2.1 [[/Actin Polymerization/]] ::5.2.2 [[/Actin Filament Cross-Linking (or “Bundling”) Proteins/]] :5.3 [[/Tubulin/]] ::5.3.1 [[/Microtubule Assembly from GTP Tubulin/]] ::5.3.2 [[/Microtubule Associated Proteins/]] :5.4 [[/Cytoskeletal Models/]] ::5.4.1 [[/Treadmilling/]] ::5.4.2 [[/Cell Crawling/]] ::5.4.3 [[/Desmosomes and Hemidesmosomes/]] ::5.4.4 [[/Skeletal Muscle Filament/]] ::5.4.5 [[/Kinesin-Dynein/]] ::5.4.6 [[/Cilia and Flagella/]] ==[[/The Cell Nucleus and Gene Expression/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Distinguish between euchromatin and heterochromatin in terms of which is the active form of genes. * Identify the components of the nuclear envelope and their functions. * Understand the roles of enhancers and repressors in gene expression. * Answer questions about gene regulation (pre- and post-transcription).
:6.1 [[/Chromosome Organization/Chromatin/]] :6.2 [[/Nuclear Organization/]] ::6.2.1 [[/Inner and Outer Membrane/]] ::6.2.2 [[/Nuclear Pore Complexes/]] ::6.2.3 [[/Transport across the nuclear envelope/]] ::6.2.4 [[/Nuclear Lamina/]] ::6.2.5 [[/Nucleolus/]] :6.3 [[/Gene Expression Transcription Unit/]] ::6.3.1 [[/RNA Polymerases/]] ::6.3.2 [[/General Transcription Factors and DNA Binding Domains/]] ::6.3.3 [[/RNA Maturation/]] ::6.3.4 [[/Ribosome/]] ::6.3.5 [[/Translation/]] :6.4 [[/Regulation of Gene Expression/]] ::6.4.1 [[/Chromatin Structure and DNA Methylation Regulates Trancription/]] ::6.4.2 [[/Repressors and Enhancers/]] ::6.4.3 [[/Inducible Systems/]] ==[[/Mitosis and Cytokinesis/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Identify what major cellular events occur at each phase of the mitotic cell cycle and during cytokinesis. * Distinguish between open and closed mitosis. * Understand how to visually identify the phases of the mitotic cycle.
:7.1 [[/Prophase/]] :7.2 [[/Prometaphase/]] :7.3 [[/Metaphase/]] :7.4 [[/Anaphase/]] ::7.4.1 [[/Anaphase A/]] ::7.4.2 [[/Anaphase B/]] :7.5 [[/Telophase/]] :7.6 [[/Cytokinesis/]] ==[[/Meiosis/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Identify what major cellular events occur at each phase of the meiotic cell cycle. * Distinguish between mitosis and meiosis in terms of both specific cellular events and the types of cells resulting from the process. * Understand the differences between oocyte formation and sperm formation.
:8.1 [[/Meiosis I/]] :8.3 [[/Meiosis II/]] :8.4 [[/Regulation of Oocyte Meiosis/]] ==[[/The Cell Cycle/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Understand what cellular events (or lack of events) occur during each phase of the cell cycle. * Identify in what phase of the cycle specific types of cells are found. * Understand the roles of cyclin and CDKs in regulating the cell cycle. * Answer questions about the cyclin/CDK pathway and what molecules/intracellular events are involved in different aspects of cell-cycle regulation.
:9.1 [[/General Phases of Cell Cycle/]] :9.2 [[/Checkpoints of Cell Cycle/]] :9.3 [[/Cyclins and Cyclin-Dependent Kinases (CDKs)/]] ::9.3.1 [[/Positive and Negative Regulators of CDK and Cyclin Pairs/]] ::9.3.2 [[/Cyclin Degradation/]] ==[[/Cellular Transport/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Understand the roles of various organelles and molecules in cellular transport. * Understand the roles of receptors in cellular transport. * Answer questions about vesicular transport and the specific functions of different types of vesicles.
:10.1 [[/Nuclear Transport/]] ::10.1.1 [[/Nuclear Import/]] ::10.1.2 [[/Nuclear Export/]] :10.2 [[/Co-translational Targeting in the Nucleus/]] ::10.2.1 [[/Signal Recognition Particle (SRP), SRP Receptor, and Translocation/]] ::10.2.3 [[/N-Linked Glycosylation and Rough ER Processing/]] :10.3 [[/Post-translational Targeting to Organelles/]] ::10.3.1 [[/Transport to Mitochondria/]] ::10.3.2 [[/Transport to Chloroplasts/]] :10.4 [[/Vesicular Transport/]] ::10.4.1 [[/COP I (Coat Complex), COP II, Clathrin, and SNARES/]] ::10.4.2 [[/Dynamin and Caveolin Families/]] ==[[/Specialized Organelle Functions/]]== Upon completion of this unit, students will be able to: * Identify specialized organelles and their specific functions. * Answer questions about where one would expect to find more of specific organelles (demonstrating an understanding of organelle function as it relates to larger tissue- and organ-wide processes). * Recognize the similarities and differences between mitochondria and chloroplasts.
:11.1 [[/Digestive Organelles/]] ::11.1.1 [[/Lysosomes/]] ::11.1.2 [[/Peroxisomes and Glyoxysomes/]] :11.2 [[/Golgi/]] ::11.2.1 [[/Structure of the Golgi/]] ::11.2.2 [[/Glycosylation, lipid and polysaccharide metabolism/]] ::11.2.3 [[/Transport of Membrane Proteins/]] :11.3 [[/Smooth ER/]] ::11.3.1 [[/Gluconeogenesis/]] ::11.3.2 [[/Detoxification and Cytochrome P450 Family/]] :11.4 [[/Mitochondria/]] :11.5 [[/Chloroplasts/]] ::11.5.1 [[/Carbon-Fixation/]] ::11.5.2 [[/Photosystem I and II/]] {{subjects|cell biology}} {{alphabetical|s}} {{alphabetical|c}} {{status|0%}}

page.title: XQuery/Converting HTML tables to XSL-FO tables

revision.text:
== Motivation == You have a collection of HTML tables that you want to convert to PDF.
== Method == We will use an XQuery typeswitch transformation that will convert the key table elements (table,thead,tr,th,db,tbody) to the corresponding XSL-FO elements.
== Sample Main Dispatcher == We will create an XQuery module with the following functions:
* a main dispater function for starting the transform * a single function for each table element * a function to process the class attributes for each element
To transform the table the following will be used:
let $fo-table := html-2-fo:main($html-table);
The main function of the {{BookCat}}

Hello, Wikibooks is not a web host and also does not permit works such as the "Snow White Rewrite" you and others are trying to create here. Please do not create any more pages as they will be deleted. Wikibooks only accepts instructional textbooks - this equally applies to class projects. For further information please see [[Wikibooks:What is Wikibooks]]. Thank you.

revision.text:
Please help me.I want to know the difference between a psychiatric rehabilitation practitioner and a psychiatrist
:There shouldn't be any difference, the practice of psychiatric rehabilitation should be an activity performed by a psychiatrist. If used in another context it will be a good indicator that the one calling himself a practitioner has no (or incomplete) formation as a psychiatrist. This of course may vary from national certifications and requirements to operate in those function(s). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 22:22, 26 April 2012 (UTC)
== Welcome message == Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]] (global to the system) or in a page on your own userspace. * Remember to use [[Commons:Main Page|Commons]] project for image uploading. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks are open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer since things work a little different here. ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to keep a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you have questions, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
<small><small>(This is not an automated message, I'll be watching during a time for any reply you make to it...)</small></small>
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 22:22, 26 April 2012 (UTC)

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Tertl3!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!

revision.comment: /* Purpose of this book */ OK but you need to give attributions to Saylor
revision.text:
==Purpose of this book==
Is this book going to be any more than a copy of the book [http://www.saylor.org/courses/bio301/ BIO301:Cell Biology] published by Saylor.org? A simple copy wouldn't really be in line with our policies (please see [[Wikibooks:What is Wikibooks?]]). [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 22:47, 26 April 2012 (UTC)
BIO301 is a course that is hosted on Saylor.org, not a book. Much of the content in that course is not openly licensed so right now Saylor just links to that material, rather than hosting it themselves. The purpose of putting the course outline (which doubles as the potential outline for text), on wikibooks, was to allow the wiki community to help write entries for the units. These entries, (and eventually, hopefully this book) will give Saylor the opportunity to host more of their resources, and provide students with a more sustainable experience. So in that way, it is much more than a simple copy.
[[User:Scphillips|Scphillips]] ([[User talk:Scphillips|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Scphillips|contribs]]) 21:46, 3 May 2012 (UTC)
:I think that could be OK then, but you need to provide attributions to Saylor.org for the material you have adapted from their course. As they say in their FAQ "...you are free to download, modify, and reproduce our course outlines for any purpose, as long as you provide credit (attribution) to the Saylor Foundation for the source material.". This can be done by inserting references to the source material in your text. (see [[Template:Reflist|Reflist]]) [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 19:23, 4 May 2012 (UTC)
